(7)  Copy of stress sheets and calculations, if deemed necessary by the department, showing the structure as designed for dead load and wind pressure as determined by the building code. 
(8)  Name, address, phone, and if available, fax and e-mail of the person erecting the sign. 
(9)  Such other information, other than the content of the message to be displayed, as the department may require to show compliance with this sign ordinance, and any other applicable laws. 
(10)  The seal or certificate of a registered structural or civil engineer, when required by the department. 
(11)  The zoning district in which the sign is to be placed. 
(12)  A notice stating: "Any change in the information in this application, such as a change of address, shall be submitted to the department within seven days after the change." 
(b)  Site plan. Three copies of a sketch illustrating where the sign will be on the site with setbacks accurately dimensioned. The sketch should also show the location of all existing buildings, roads, parking areas, signs, entrances and exits on the site. 
(c)  Sign drawing. Three copies of a drawing of the proposed sign(s) shall include all of the following detailed information. 
(1)  Height of the sign above finished grade. 
(2)  Surface of the sign (material, color and dimensions.) 
(3)  Dimensions and display area of the proposed sign. 
(4)  The proposed graphic images and text to be displayed on the sign. 
(5)  Such additional information and detail as the director of community development deems necessary and/or pertinent to the application. 
(d)  Neighborhood identification signs. Applications for neighborhood identification signs shall include the following additional documents and information: 
(1)  A description of the property interest of the applicant and any other parties interest to the site where the identification sign will be located. 
(2)  Evidence, satisfactory to the township attorney, of the right to construct such identification sign on the site. 
(3)  Existing or proposed sign and landscape easement(s) for the identification sign. 
(4)  Existing or proposed neighborhood identification sign construction and maintenance agreement. 
Applications for neighborhood identification signs shall be submitted and reviewed separately from the subdivision or site plan review process. 
(e)  Portable signs. All information required for the submission of permanent signs shall be required for the submission of a portable sign. 
(f)  Review procedures. The department shall have the sole authority to approve or deny applications for portable or permanent signs. The department shall review the application for conformance with the requirements of the article. The department may refer any application for sign approval to the board of appeals for their review. The application shall be either approved or denied within 14 days of the submittal date. Submittals shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Sign applications that conform to all applicable ordinance standards shall be approved. 
(2)  All applications for sign permits that are incomplete or do not meet the requirements of this article shall be denied. 
(3)  An approval of a sign permit may be conditioned upon compliance with reasonable conditions or limitations regarding the character of the sign, the surroundings in which it is to be displayed, and the purpose of this article. 
(4)  Approved applications for permanent signs shall be reviewed by the township building department for conformity with all building codes in effect in the township, and if in compliance therewith, the building inspector shall issue the appropriate sign permit. 
(g)  Permit fees. Permit fees for signs shall be established by resolution of the governing body of this municipality. The permit fees must relate to the cost of issuing the permit and may vary based on the size, type, and height of the sign. 
(h)  False information. A person providing false information under this article shall be guilty of a civil infraction. 
(i)  Permits issued. Applicants meeting the provision of this article shall be issued a permit within 14 of submitting a complete application. 
(Ord. No. 657, 1-26-2004)  
Sec. 48-13. - Administration. 
(a)  Administrator. The department shall appoint personnel to administer and enforce the terms and conditions of this article and all other provisions relating to signs. 
(b)  Enforcement. The department shall issue permits, as required by this article. The department shall also ensure signs comply with this article and any other applicable law. The department shall also enforce the requirement that all signs properly comply with this article by procuring a permit. The department shall make such inspections as may be necessary and shall initiate appropriate action to enforce compliance with this article and other applicable sign laws. 
(c)  Department powers. The department shall have the power and authority to administer and enforce this article. Included among such powers are the following specific powers: 
(1)  Every sign for which a permit is required shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the department. When deemed advisable, a sign may be inspected at the point of manufacture. 
(2)  Upon presentation of proper identification to the sign owner or owner's agent, the department may enter the sign area for purposes of inspecting the sign, sign structure, and any fasteners securing the sign to a building or support. 
In cases of emergency, where imminent hazards to persons or property are known to exist, and where the sign owner, or owner's agent, is not readily available, the department may enter the sign area for purposes of inspection or remediation. When on private property, the department shall observe rules and regulations concerning safety, internal security, and fire protection. 
If the department is denied admission to inspect any sign, inspection shall be made only under authority of a warrant issued by a court of proper jurisdiction. When applying for such warrant, the department shall submit an affidavit setting forth a belief that a violation of this article exists with respect to a particular sign, and the reasons for forming this belief. The affidavit shall designate the place and name of the person believed to own or possess the sign. If the court finds probable cause exists for the search of the sign, and supporting structures, then a warrant authorizing the search shall be issued. The warrant shall describe the property with sufficient certainty to identify the same. This warrant shall constitute authority for the department to enter the sign area and to inspect the property. 
(3)  Upon issuance of a stop order from the department, work on any sign that is being conducted in any manner contrary to this article shall be immediately stopped. This notice and order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the parcel, the sign owner, or to the person performing the work. The stop order shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. The police department shall have authority to enforce a stop order. 
(4)  The department has the authority to revoke any permit authorized by this article if the sign violates this article or another law, provided that the department shall offer the sign owner an opportunity to be heard. The person whose permit is under consideration shall be given at least ten days written notice of the time, place, and reason for the hearing. The sign owner and/or person identified in the permit shall be permitted to present relevant facts and legal argument concerning the pending revocation. Following this hearing, the department shall consider the merits of the case and shall present a written opinion prior to any action. If, however, the department believes the health, safety, or welfare of the citizens is endangered by any violation of this article, the department may immediately revoke any sign permits. 
(5)  A sign installed after the effective date of this article, and not conforming to this article, shall be removed by the owner. The sign owner shall not be entitled to compensation for the sign removal and shall reimburse the department for any costs incurred in connection with the removal. 
(6)  Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a civil infraction. Each day on which a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, the municipal attorney is authorized to take all action, legal, injunctive and equitable, to assure compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 657, 1-26-2004)  
Sec. 48-14. - Sign board of appeals. 
(a)  Sign board of appeals. The Saginaw Charter Township Zoning Board of Appeals shall constitute the sign board of appeals for the purpose of this article and a quorum shall consist of three members. 
(b)  Appeals authorized: 
(1)  Any person aggrieved by a decision of the building inspector or code enforcement officer relative to the placement, area, height and construction of a sign may appeal such decision to the township sign board of appeals. Such appeal shall be taken by the zoning administrator. 
(2)  The sign board of appeals shall have the power to interpret the provisions of this ordinance in such a way as to carry out the intent and purpose of this ordinance. The authority to alter or change the sign ordinance is reserved to the Township Board. 
(3)  Whenever the strict application of requirements of this article may pose demonstrable practical difficulty with regard to placement, area, height and construction of a sign an appeal for variance from such requirements may be filed with the zoning administrator on a form provided for such purpose. 
(4)  The zoning administrator or his/her designee(s) shall then place the appeal on a regular meeting agenda of the board of appeals within 30 days of filing. 
(5)  Within 60 days of receipt, the board of appeals shall render a final decision in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(6)  A decision of the board shall become final upon approval of the minutes of the meeting or the expiration of five township business days from the date of the decision, whichever occurs sooner, unless the board finds that immediate effect is necessary to preserve a substantial property right, and so certifies in the record of the decision. 
(c)  Fees. Any person filing an appeal with the township sign board of appeals shall fill out the necessary appeal form provided by the zoning administrator and shall pay a filing fee, as established by resolution of the township board. 
(d)  Appeal procedure. 
(1)  The zoning administrator or his/her designee(s) shall give notice of all hearings to all owners of record of real property within 300 feet of the premises in question; such notice shall be delivered by first class mail addressed to the respective owners at the address given in the last assessment roll. 
(2)  All persons appealing shall be required to appear in person or to be represented by a duly authorized agent. 
(3)  The board of appeals shall prepare an official record for each appeal and shall base its decision on this record. The official record shall include: 
a.  The relevant administrative records and administrative orders issued herein relating to the appeal. 
b.  The appeal form. 
c.  The requisite written findings of fact, the conditions attached, the decisions and orders by the board of appeals disposing the appeal, signed by the chairman of the board. 
d.  Any other documentation submitted in support or opposition of the appeal. 
(4)  The appellant shall be prepared to furnish a site drawing, photograph, and any other means of proof, to the sign board of appeals to demonstrate that a hardship or practical difficulty exists. 
(e)  Action of sign board of appeals. 
(1)  The sign board of appeals shall have the power to modify or reverse, wholly or partly, the notice or order, and may grant an extension of time for the performance of any act required of not more than three additional months, where the sign board of appeals finds that there is a practical difficulty resulting from the application of the provisions of this article, and that such extension is in harmony with the general purpose of this article to secure the public health, safety and welfare. 
(2)  The sign board of appeals shall return a decision upon each petition within 60 days after a request or appeal has been filed, unless a longer time is agreed upon by the parties concerned; however, the sign board of appeals may not order action on a petition until its regularly scheduled meeting. 
(3)  The concurring vote of a majority of the members of the sign board of appeals shall be necessary to reverse, wholly or partly, or modify any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the building official or code enforcement officer; or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which the sign board of appeals required to consider or to effect any variation the provisions of this article. 
(4)  After a variance has been denied in whole or in part by the sign board of appeals, then such petition shall not be resubmitted for a period of one year from the date of the last denial, provided however, that a denied variance may be reconsidered by the sign board of appeals within said one-year period, when, in the opinion of the building official, or code enforcement officer or sign board of appeals, newly discovered evidence or changed conditions warrant such reconsideration. 
(5)  Scope of hearing. At the hearing, the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to show cause why the notice or order should be modified or withdrawn, or why the period of time permitted for compliance should be extended. 
(f)  Stay. An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the building inspector certifies to the sign board of appeals, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate, imminent harm to persons or property exists, in which case the proceedings shall not be stayed, except by an order of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(g)  Variances. A variance may be allowed by the sign board of appeals in cases only involving practical difficulties when the evidence in the official record of the appeal supports all of the following affirmative findings: 
(1)  That the alleged practical difficulties are exceptional and peculiar to the property of the person requesting the variance, and result from conditions which do not exist generally throughout the township. 
(2)  That the alleged practical difficulties which will result from a failure to grant the variance, include substantially more than mere inconvenience, or mere inability to attain a higher financial return. 
(3)  That allowing the variance will result in substantial justice being done, considering the public benefits intended to be secured by this article, the individual hardships that will be suffered by a failure to grant a variance, and the rights of others whose property would be affected by the allowance of the variance, and will not be contrary to the public purpose and general intent and purpose of this article. 
The above findings of fact shall be made by the sign board of appeals, which is not empowered to grant a variance without an affirmative finding of fact in each of the categories above. Every finding of fact shall be supported in the record of the proceedings of the board. 
(4)  In the case of an appeal for extension of the useful life of a nonconforming sign, the sign board of appeals finds that there is significant useful life remaining in the sign based on recent maintenance and initial capital costs that has not been amortized by the owner or leasee. 
(h)  Review by circuit court. Any party aggrieved by a final decision of the board of appeals may obtain a review thereof both on the facts and the law in Saginaw County Circuit Court. 
(Ord. No. 657, 1-26-2004; Ord. No. 700, 2-27-2008)  
Chapter 50 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 26; trash, rubbish, junk, or junk vehicles, § 26-34; littering, § 38-8. 
State Law reference Solid waste management, MCL 324.11501 et seq.; littering, MCL 324.8901 et seq.; hazardous waste, MCL 324.11101 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 50-1. - Littering and related offenses. 
(a)  Wind blown dust, ashes, or trash. It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate, except in a covered container, any dust, ashes or trash of such a material that it can be blown away by the wind anywhere in the township. 
(b)  Deposits on streets or alleys. It shall be unlawful to deposit or permit to be deposited or permit to fall from any vehicle any dirt, garbage, refuse building material, rubbish or ashes on any public street or alley in the township; provided, that this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit placing garbage, refuse or ashes in a container or receptacle complying with the conditions of this chapter prior to having such material collected and disposed of in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(c)  Accumulation on public/private property. No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited, sort, scatter, or leave any rubbish, refuse building materials, garbage, ashes, cinders, grass, leaves, twigs or shrubs, manure or filth or other offensive materials in any public street, alley, private or public property in the township, or build or maintain any structure or thing whatsoever containing such materials. It shall be the responsibility of every property owner to provide for the removal of all refuse, trash, discarded materials, recyclables, etc., found on his property. 
(d)  Unlawful dumping without owner's consent. It shall be unlawful to dump or place any garbage, refuse or ashes on any premises in the township without the consent of the owner of such premises. 
(Code 1986, §§ 3-02.07.013-02.07.04) 
State Law reference Littering, MCL 324.8901 et seq.  
Secs. 50-250-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
 
Sec. 50-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Construction refuse means all unwanted, rejected, discarded or abandoned materials resulting from the alteration, repair, or construction of buildings. 
Dead animals means the carcasses of small animals, fish, or fowl, but does not include carcasses from large animals or from veterinary hospitals or clinics. 
Dwelling unit means a separate dwelling place with a kitchen. 
Garbage means animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, service, and consumption of food. 
Garbage and refuse collection/collection means the taking up and collecting of all garbage and refuse accumulated in containers at single-family and duplex dwelling residences within its jurisdiction, and the transportation to a sanitary landfill or other place of legal disposal to be selected by the contractor and provided at the sole expense of the contractor. 
Hazardous refuse means anything dangerous to the public health, safety, or welfare and shall include drugs, volatile or radioactive materials, gas and oils, poisons, explosives, and diseased or contaminated materials. 
Industrial refuse means rejected, unwanted, discarded, or abandoned materials resulting from industrial operations such as is generally identified with manufacturing, assembling, processing, and distributing plants, large office buildings, hospitals, and clinics, and other producers of quantities of refuse in excess amounts. 
Receptacle, unless specifically provided otherwise, whether referred to as "garbage can," "plastic bag," "suitable container," "cans," or "containers," means a receptacle which shall be of such size and form as to permit collection by one person. 
(1)  Garbage cans shall not exceed 30 gallons in capacity and shall be fitted with handles and lids. 
(2)  All trees, wood, lumber, hedge and tree trimmings or other items, except appliances and furniture, must be in lengths not exceeding 36 inches and bundles not exceeding 24 inches in diameter. 
Recyclable materials means newsprint, unsorted glass (food and beverage containers), unsorted aluminum, steel, bimetal, and "tin" cans (food and beverage containers), and other materials as mutually agreed upon by the township and contractor. 
(1)  Recyclable materials shall also include polyethylene trephthalate (PETE), high density polyethylene (HDPE), corrugated cardboard, and other materials as mutually agreed upon by the township and the contractor. 
(2)  Recyclable materials also include all items of refuse designated by the township to be part of an authorized recycling program and which are intended for transportation for processing and remanufacturing or reuse. 
Recycling containers means uniform receptacles supplied by the township in which recycled materials can be stored and later be placed at curbside or other locations for collection as specified by the contract. 
Recycling service means the picking up of all recyclable materials accumulated in recycling containers at single-family and duplex homes or at locations as mutually agreed upon by the township and the contractor. 
Refuse means all wastes which normally result from the operation of a household, except body waste, garbage, and yard waste, including, but not limited to, rubbish, metal cans, papers, cardboard, glass jars, bottles, wood, ashes, sod, dirt, rocks, household construction materials, cement, bricks, household appliances, furniture, water heaters, water softeners, plastics, and any other household refuse or materials small enough for one person to handle. The term "refuse" shall not include leaves or grass clippings, nor shall it include building materials or other waste or debris resulting from construction or reconstruction of buildings and other improvements by contractors. 
Unacceptable recyclable materials means materials which are not acceptable for reprocessing and use in another form and recyclable materials which have not been properly prepared and/or located in compliance with the provisions of the contract. 
Yard waste means compostible, organic material consisting of grass clippings, hedge and tree prunings, weeds, brush, leaves, and other yard wastes, excluding trees. Brush may be in bundles not exceeding 24 inches in diameter nor 36 inches in length. Only one bundle may be placed for pickup per week. 
Yard waste collection means the taking and receipt of all yard waste accumulated in yard waste receptacles and bundles at all single-family and duplex homes in the township. Yard waste shall be kept unmixed from other types of waste or refuse. Collection shall also include transportation to a township approved compost site. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.02) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 50-32. - Intent. 
It is the intent of the township board that this article be liberally construed for the purpose of providing a sanitary and satisfactory method of preparation, collection and disposition of municipal waste. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.03.01)  
Sec. 50-33. - Power and duties of township manager. 
(a)  The township manager is hereby authorized to make such rules and regulations as from time to time appear to him to be necessary to carry out the intent of this article, provided, that such rules are not in conflict with this or any other Code provisions of the township. 
(b)  The collection and removal of waste shall be under the supervision of the township manager or his authorized representative. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the township manager or his authorized representative and the ordinance enforcement officer to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.03.02)  
Sec. 50-34. - Disposal by owner or producer. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to prohibit or deny the owner or producer of refuse his right to dispose of his own refuse if in so doing he does not violate any provisions of this article. 
(b)  No person shall contract with any individual, firm or corporation to collect, transport or dispose of refuse within the corporate limits of the township unless such individual, firm or corporation is duly licensed by the township to collect, transport and dispose of refuse. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.05.07)  
Sec. 50-35. - Authorized recycling material/containers. 
(a)  Due to the rapidly changing technology in the area of recycling, authorized recyclable materials and authorized containers may change from time to time based upon available markets, transportation vehicle sizes, and pickup methods. 
(b)  The township shall provide a leaflet containing a list and details of the current authorized recyclable materials and authorized containers. Such leaflets shall be available for pickup by the public at the manager's office, township hall. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.03.03)  
Sec. 50-36. - Curbside recycling voluntary initially. 
Curbside recycling in the township shall be on a voluntary basis until such time that it will become mandatory. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.03.04)  
Sec. 50-37. - License for refuse collection. 
No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting or disposing of refuse in the township without first obtaining a business license. Any license issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the township manager for any violation of any law or Code provision pertaining to the operation or maintenance of such establishment. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.04)  
Sec. 50-38. - Storage receptacles. 
(a)  Portable waste receptacles. The owner, occupant or lessee, or their agents, of every building where wastes accumulate, including multiple dwellings as defined in the state housing code, shall cause to be provided for such building, proper receptacles as required in this article. 
(1)  Metal or plastic with cover for garbage. 
a.  For garbage, receptacles shall be portable, so maintained as to be watertight and vermin proof, and not exceed 30-gallon capacity, each. 
b.  Receptacles shall be of substantial metal or plastic construction and provided with handles or bails and a tightfitting cover. 
c.  Receptacles containing more than 50 pounds of rubbish are not acceptable for pickup. 
d.  Receptacles that are broken or otherwise fail to meet the requirements of this article may be deemed to be rubbish and, after due notice to the users, shall be repaired or removed and replaced. 
(2)  Plastic bags. Plastic bags, or portable weathertight containers, may be collected as rubbish without notice, but must be of a size not to exceed 30 pounds in weight when full. 
(b)  Compact bundles. Rubbish that cannot be contained in receptacles must be securely tied in compact bundles, not to exceed 50 pounds in weight or exceed three feet in length or two feet in diameter to be acceptable for scheduled pickup and disposal. 
(c)  Condition of receptacle or contents. No person shall disturb the contents of any portable waste or recycle receptacle or bundle, nor leave the containers or contents in a condition other than this article provides. All containers shall be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(d)  Refuse collection truck containers. In every case where the owner, occupant or user of any premises shall accumulate more than one cubic yard of refuse in any one week period, it shall be mandatory to provide a container or containers of the type designed to be handled mechanically by refuse collection trucks in place of the normal receptacles provided in this section, commonly referred to as "dumpsters." Such container or containers shall be: 
(1)  Of substantial metal construction having a capacity large enough to contain normal waste, tightfitting covers and handles so that such container or containers may be unloaded into the refuse collection truck by mechanical means provided by the truck; 
(2)  Kept clean and in good condition at all times; 
(3)  Kept only on a concrete or adequate asphalt pad on the premises of the owner, occupant or user of such premises; and 
(4)  Enclosed with an opaque fence or appropriate plantings. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.05.01)  
Sec. 50-39. - Disturbing refuse receptacles/contents. 
No person, excluding agents or employees of licensees of the township, without the property owners permission, shall disturb, remove, or attempt to remove refuse receptacles, their covers, or the contents of any receptacle or refuse container, or disturb or remove or attempt to remove any refuse and/or recyclable not in containers whether the receptacle or refuse container is on public or private property. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.07.05)  
Sec. 50-40. - Preparation of refuse for disposal. 
(a)  Garbage drained and wrapped. Garbage must be thoroughly drained of liquids and be wrapped in several thicknesses of paper before being placed in receptacles for collection. 
(b)  Combustible refuse. Refuse classified and described in this article as combustible may be placed in the same containers as garbage if all the other requirements of this section are adhered to. Other combustible refuse must be tied in bundles with nonmetallic materials or placed in proper receptacles. 
(c)  Noncombustible refuse. Noncombustible refuse as previously defined shall be placed in proper containers or tied in bundles to facilitate handling wherever possible. In the case of articles not conforming to weight or dimension limitations, special arrangements for pickup and disposal must be made with a licensed refuse hauler. 
(d)  Maximum accumulation period. No garbage, rubbish, or noncombustible refuse shall be stored or allowed to accumulate on property in the township for more than 14 days. 
(e)  Yard waste. Yard wastes, which include grass, leaves, twigs, and branches, may be composted, provided that the accumulation of such waste does not exceed one cubic yard, be maintained in bins or approved enclosures, follow the required setbacks for accessory structures as determined in the township zoning ordinance (appendix A), and does not emit offensive odors or impair the health, comfort, or welfare of neighboring property owners. 
(f)  Construction and building materials. It shall be the duty of the owner, contractor, occupant, or other person responsible for construction work to remove from the premises within a reasonable time after the completion of such construction work, all surplus construction material and all refuse building material and all construction refuse. Such materials shall be removed to an appropriate site. 
(g)  Hazardous refuse. Hazardous refuse as previously defined shall be the responsibility of the producer or owner thereof and shall not be disposed of within the township, or allowed to be stored or transported within the township: 
(1)  Without the written approval of the township manager or his authorized agent; and 
(2)  Then only under the supervision of someone appointed by him who has knowledge of the safety measures necessary to protect the public health and safety during such storing, transporting, or disposing of hazardous refuse. 
(h)  Recyclables. All recyclables must be maintained according to the regulations set forth by the collection agency. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.05.02)  
Sec. 50-41. - Placement at road edge. 
No refuse and or recyclables shall be placed at the curb or street for collection more than 14 hours prior to the morning of the time scheduled for collection, or between 3:00 p.m. on Fridays and 5:00 p.m. on Sundays unless arrangements have been made for pickup within 14 hours after being placed for collection or pickup scheduled on Saturday due to a holiday. Placement of refuse shall be within three feet at road edge. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.05.03)  
Sec. 50-42. - Removal of empty receptacles. 
After the collection of container contents have been made, the empty container shall be removed from the curb or street and replaced on the owner's storage area, protected so that they cannot be easily disturbed by animals and in a reasonably inconspicuous place and away from places occupied by other persons and from streets as soon as possible, but in no case later than 12 hours after collection of refuse has been made. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.05.04)  
Sec. 50-43. - Collection vehicles. 
Vehicles used for collection and transportation of refuse within or through the township shall be watertight, covered, and conform to all laws regulating axle and road limitations. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.05.05)  
Sec. 50-44. - Disposal of collected refuse. 
All refuse collected for disposal from within the corporate limits of the township shall be disposed of at an approved facility, licensed landfill or refuse disposal authority. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.05.06)  
Sec. 50-45. - Rates and charges. 
The rates for refuse collection for single-family residences, or duplex units shall be established by resolution of the township board based on contract costs and other township expenses and relevant considerations. 
(Code 1986, § 3-02.06)  
Chapter 54 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment saved from repeal, § 1-11(9); administration, ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 
State Law reference Notice and hearings for special assessments, MCL 211.741; assumpsit to collect permit assessments, MCL 211.501 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 54-154-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENT HARDSHIP DEFERMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 696, adopted May 29, 2007, amended Art. II in its entirety by repealing Ord. No. 589, adopted Jan. 25, 1999, from which derived §§ 54-3154-36, and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former Art. II pertained to street repaving special assessment hardship deferment. 
State Law reference Deferment of special assessments on homesteads, MCL 211.761 et seq. 
 
Sec. 54-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Committee means a three-person panel comprised of the township supervisor, the township clerk and the director of assessing or their designated appointees. 
Farm and farm products shall be as defined in MCL 286.471. 
Homestead means a single-family dwelling owned and occupied as a home by the owner thereof, including all contiguous unoccupied real property owned by the person. 
Household income is defined by the Income Tax Act of 1967 (MCL 206.1 et seq.), as the sum of federal adjusted gross income plus all income specifically excluded or exempt from the computation of federal adjusted gross income. 
Owner means any person eligible for the exemption specified in this article, who owns or is purchasing a homestead, as defined in this section, under a mortgage or land contract or who owns and operates a farm as defined in this section. 
Special assessment means any special assessment against real property levied pursuant to Public Act No. 188 of 1954 (MCL 41.721 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 696, 5-29-2007)  
Sec. 54-32. - Deferred payments of special assessments based on hardship. 
(1)  Homestead deferment. 
(a)  The committee may grant deferrals of special assessment payments of persons who, in the opinion of the committee, by reason of hardship are unable to contribute toward the cost thereof, in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  An owner may apply for deferment of any special assessment on the owner's homestead. The application shall be made upon an affidavit form available from the township assessor. 
1.  The affidavit form shall contain the following: 
a.  The name, or names if owned jointly, and social security number of the applicant. 
b.  The homestead address. 
c.  The home and business telephone number of the applicant. 
d.  The length of ownership of the homestead by the applicant. 
e.  Total household income for the past calendar year. The applicant shall attach copies of the most recently filed federal and state income tax forms of all members of the household, including all schedules, to the application. 
f.  Current place of employment. If the applicant is unemployed, the date of termination or resignation from employment shall be stated. 
g.  A statement of the annual income of all household members as of the date of the application. 
h.  The number of dependents, as defined in 26 U.S.C. 1 et seq., of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended, residing with the applicant at the homestead. 
i.  If the applicant is over 65 years of age or totally and permanently disabled, the applicant shall attach a copy of the notice from the treasurer denying deferment of special assessment under MCL 211.765, as amended, to the application. 
j.  The amount of the special assessment installment payment for which deferment is requested and the date such assessment comes or was due. 
k.  A statement located immediately above the applicant's signature: "It is understood that if this deferment is authorized, the Township will place a lien on your property." 
l.  The form shall be signed by the applicant and notarized. If the homestead is owned jointly by husband and wife, both shall sign and file the affidavit. 
2.  In addition to the above, copies of the following documents shall be attached to the application: 
a.  Recorded deed and land contract or mortgage for the homestead property. 
b.  The cover page of the current homeowners or hazard insurance policy covering the homestead. 
c.  A death certificate or divorce decree, if such document affects the title to the homestead property. 
d.  Any other document that the township may require to process the application for deferment. 
(2)  Farm hardship deferment. 
(a)  An owner may apply for deferment of a special assessment on the owner's farm. The application shall be made upon an affidavit form available from the township treasurer. 
1.  The affidavit form shall contain the following: 
a.  The name, or names if owned jointly, and social security number of the applicant. 
b.  The farm address. 
c.  The home and business telephone number of the applicant. 
d.  The length of ownership of the farm by the applicant. 
e.  A certificate of survey of the farm or, if none available, an accurate legal description. 
f.  A certificate as to the nature and extent of operations on all of the property in order to meet the definition of "farm" and "farm products." 
g.  A statement that the farm is not eligible for relief from special assessments under MCL 324.36108. 
h.  The amount of the special assessment installment payment for which deferment is requested and the date such special assessment comes or was due. 
i.  A statement located immediately above the applicant's signature: "It is understood that if this deferment is authorized, the Township will place a lien on your property." 
j.  The form shall be signed by the applicant and notarized. If the farm is owned jointly by husband and wife, both shall sign and file the affidavit. 
2.  In addition to the above, copies of the following documents shall be attached to the application: 
a.  Recorded deed and land contract or mortgage for the farm property. 
b.  All documents which confirm existence of farm operation. 
c.  A death certificate or divorce decree, if such document affects the title to the homestead property. 
d.  Any other document that the township may require to process the application for deferment. 
e.  Application for deferment of a special assessment must be made no later than 30 days after the due date of a special assessment for which deferment is requested. 
f.  To qualify for a deferment of a special assessment for a homestead, the applicant must meet all of the following requirements: 
(i)  Total household income attributed to the applicant in the past calendar year cannot exceed $25,000.00, adjusted, annually, by the Consumers Price Index, with 2007 used as the base year. 
(ii)  The homestead must be the primary residence of the applicant; 
(iii)  The homestead must have been owned and occupied by the applicant for at least three years; 
(iv)  The applicant cannot be eligible for deferment of special assessment under MCL 211.761, et seq., as amended; 
(v)  Property taxes on the homestead property should not be more than two years delinquent. 
g.  To qualify for a deferment of a special assessment for a farm, the applicant must meet all of the following requirements: 
(i)  The parcel for which deferment is requested must be ten acres in size or larger and must have been in operation as a farm and producing farm products for at least one year prior to application. 
(ii)  The applicant cannot be eligible for relief from a special assessment under MCL 324.36108, as amended. 
(iii)  Property taxes on the farm property should not be more than two years delinquent. 
h.  Immediately upon receipt of the affidavit form, the assessor shall stamp the application with the time and date of receipt. The assessor shall promptly examine the application to determine if the applicant meets the requirements of this chapter. 
(i)  The assessor shall make an inspection of the property and property records and conduct an investigation and survey as he deems necessary. An applicant shall not be compelled to supply information not reasonably necessary to a proper determination of the eligibility of the owner and the homestead for the relief provided under this section. 
(ii)  The committee shall promptly make a decision and shall notify the applicant of this decision not later than 30 days after the receipt of the application. In lieu of a deferment the committee may grant an extension in the number of years and other terms over which an assessment must be paid. The decision of the committee shall be final. 
i.  The payment of any special assessment due and payable on a homestead or farm for which the owner meets all the eligibility requirements of this section shall be deferred until the occurrence of the first of the following events: 
(i)  For a homestead deferment the homestead or any part of the homestead is conveyed or transferred to another provided, however, that: 
A.  The original applicant for the deferral may convey or transfer an interest in the homestead to another person jointly with the applicant provided that the original applicant continues to reside at the homestead; or 
B.  An owner who owns the property jointly with another may convey or transfer that interest to the original applicant for the deferral provided that the original applicant to whom the property is conveyed continues to reside at the homestead; 
(ii)  A land contract selling the homestead is entered into; 
(iii)  The owner fails to maintain adequate homeowners and hazard insurance as required herein; or 
(iv)  One year after the original applicant's death, subject to further order of the probate court; however, the death of a spouse shall not terminate the deferment of a special assessment for a household owned by husband and wife as long as the spouse does not remarry. 
(v)  The owner leases or rents the property to a third party and ceases to occupy it as a principal residence. 
j.  For a farm deferment the farm or any part of the farm is conveyed or transferred to another, or the property is split into parcels of less than ten acres or a permit is sought from the township to improve the parcel. 
k.  Payment of deferred amounts. 
l.  A change in one or more of the original conditions for granting of a deferment under f.(i)(v) or g.(i)(iii) above, which would render the applicant ineligible for a deferment. 
(i)  Any special assessment deferred under this section may be paid at anytime. 
(ii)  Upon the occurrence of any one of the events terminating a deferment of a special assessment under subsection 54-31.e. or f., above, the deferred amount plus interest shall be paid in full. 
(iii)  If the owner fails to make such payment when the deferment is terminated, the provisions of this chapter regarding the collection of special assessments shall again apply to the deferred payment as if no deferment had been granted and the township may enforce the lien upon the property in any manner permitted by law. 
m.  Interest shall accrue on deferred special assessments at the monthly rate provided for nondeferred installment payments within the special assessment district. 
n.  The treasurer shall send to the owner, by first class mail, a yearly statement showing the amounts of a deferred assessment on the homestead and the interest outstanding thereon. 
o.  Notice of lien. 
(i)  Upon grant of a deferment, the township shall record a notice of lien in its favor at the Saginaw County Register of Deeds stating that there exists a lien upon such property for deferred special assessments. The lien created shall include the amount of interest provided hereunder. 
(ii)  The owner shall sign all documents necessary for the filing of such lien as a condition to receiving a deferral. 
p.  For homestead deferments and for the duration of the deferment, the owner shall maintain homeowners and hazard insurance on the homestead in an amount not less than the amount of the deferred assessment(s) and accrued interest plus the balance of any mortgage or other lien or encumbrance superior to the township's lien. On or before June 1st of each year for the duration of the deferment, the owner shall provide the treasurer with proof of such homeowners and hazard insurance in the form of a certificate of insurance, and such certificate of insurance shall show the township as an additional insured and shall further contain a clause requiring the insurance company to give the township 30 days advance notice of cancellation, termination or material change in the insurance coverage. 
q.  Nothing in this chapter shall give any person a vested right to receive a deferment or in the standards to be applied in granting such a deferment. 
(i)  The township may change, modify, or delete any of the terms and conditions of this section or repeal it in its entirety at any time without notice to any applicant or recipient of a deferment. 
(ii)  However, once a deferment is granted, it cannot be revoked and payment be required prior to the time set forth in this section. 
r.  Penalties. 
(i)  In addition to all other penalties imposed by this chapter, if any person shall make a false or misleading statement on an application for deferment under this section, such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and all amounts deferred shall be immediately due and payable. 
(ii)  Failure to pay such deferrals within 30 days of receiving notice from the treasurer shall result in the foreclosure of the liens placed upon the subject property pursuant to this section. 
(iii)  Violation of this article is a municipal civil infraction and the sanction for such violation shall be a civil fine in the amount as provided by this Code or any other ordinance plus costs, damages, expenses and other sanctions as authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 696, 5-29-2007)  
Chapter 58 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment saved from repeal, § 1-11(9); any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, sidewalk or alley saved from repeal, § 1-11(10); any ordinance establishing the grade of any street or sidewalk saved from repeal, § 1-11(11); buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 26; floods, ch. 34; obstructing public places, § 38-153; parks and recreation, ch. 42; peddlers, charitable solicitors and temporary businesses, ch. 46; peddlers, § 46-31 et seq.; special assessments, ch. 54; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 62; design standards for streets and alleys, § 62-75; required improvements of streets and roads, § 62-98; telecommunications, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 74; riding bicycles on sidewalks, § 74-43; utilities, ch. 78; vegetation, ch. 82; zoning, app. A; arterial street access driveway regulations, app. A, § 2401 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 58-1. - Operation of off-road vehicles. 
(1)  The definitions set forth in Section 81101(a) through (ff) of Act 451 of 1994, as amended, (MCL 81101(a)(ff)) are hereby adopted. 
(2)  Effective February 12, 2014, the operation of off-road vehicles (ORVs) on all roads and streets within Saginaw Charter Township is prohibited. 
( Ord. No. 738, §§ 1, 2, 2-10-2014 )  
Secs. 58-258-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 58-31. - Areas where required. 
Areas in which sidewalks may be required by the township board are as follows: 
(1)  All section line and quarter section line roads; 
(2)  Brockway; 
(3)  Wieneke; 
(4)  Fashion Square Boulevard and Fortune Boulevard; 
(5)  Towne Center Road (west side only); 
(6)  Midland Road from Gratiot to Winterstein Drain (west side only); 
(7)  Midland Road from Winterstein Drain to State Street (east side only). 
(Code 1986, § 4-02.02)  
Sec. 58-32. - Obstructions prohibited. 
No person shall allow any sidewalk which crosses or adjoins any property owned or occupied by him to be obstructed by vehicles, bicycles, trailers, equipment, signs, snow, ice, or in any other manner that prevents the normal use of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1986, § 4-02.04.03)  
Sec. 58-33. - Responsible party liable for damages. 
Any damage to a sidewalk caused by construction work occurring on any adjoining property shall be repaired at the expense of the adjoining property owner; provided, however, that responsibility for repair of damage to a sidewalk caused by a utility or construction company not in connection with work done on the adjoining property shall be paid for by the responsible utility or construction company. 
(Code 1986, § 4-02.04.04)  
Secs. 58-3458-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION OR REPAIR 
 
Sec. 58-51. - Generally. 
(a)  Permit. No person shall construct or repair any sidewalk without first obtaining a written authorization therefor from the township community development department. 
(b)  Specifications. Construction or repair shall be in accordance with all standards of the township. 
(c)  Sidewalk committee. There is created a township sidewalk committee to be appointed by the township board consisting of one member of the township planning commission, one member of the township board, and three members of the public at large, who shall serve for terms of three years. The committee shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the township board an annual budget relating to sidewalks; 
(2)  To determine and recommend to the township board an annual sidewalk construction program; 
(3)  To act on requests for extensions of time relating to installation of sidewalks as provided in this article; 
(4)  To consider and approve or reject requested variances in the location or specifications as provided in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 4-02.03)  
Sec. 58-52. - Sidewalk and drive approach maintenance. 
(a)  Crossing or adjoining property. No person shall permit any sidewalk which crosses or adjoins property owned by him to fall into a state of disrepair, be unsafe, or impassable. 
(b)  Between lot line and street curb. Except as to sidewalks located along streets set forth in section 58-31, which shall be the responsibility of the township, all sidewalks and driveway approaches between the lot line and the street curb or improved street, shall be repaired and maintained by the abutting property owner and shall comply with all requirements of this article. If any owner shall neglect to keep or maintain these sidewalks and driveway approaches in good repair and safe for use of the public, the owner shall be liable to the township for any damages recovered against the township sustained by any person by reason of such sidewalk being unsafe and out-of-repair, in addition to the other penalties provided for in this article. 
(Code 1986, §§ 4-02.04.01, 4-02.04.02)  
Sec. 58-53. - Expenses. 
(a)  Before the township board may require any owner of any lot or premises to construct, maintain, or to pay for the expense of construction or maintenance of a sidewalk across or adjoining their lot or premises by the township, the township board shall first hold a public hearing relative to the requiring of the sidewalk construction or repair and shall notify all property owners involved of the time and place of the hearing by regular first-class mail directed to the last-known address of such owners as indicated by the township tax rolls; provided, however, that a public hearing need not be held for sidewalks required to be constructed in newly developed subdivisions and for new construction developments. 
(b)  Unless otherwise approved by the township board, the expense of construction of such sidewalks as designated in section 56-31 shall be charged as follows: 
(1)  In newly developed subdivisions: Entire cost to be borne by the developer. 
(2)  Adjacent to all new construction, regardless of zoning: Entire cost to be borne by developer or builder. 
(3)  Adjacent to all existing developments containing any multifamily use with more than two units and all developments zoned or used for R-3, R-4, M-1, M-2, and all B zoning purposes: The cost will be shared equally by the township and owners of the premises. 
(4)  Along designated roads adjacent to existing R-1 and R-2 development: The entire cost of original construction shall be borne by the township. 
(c)  When the cost of sidewalk construction in existing developed areas is to be borne wholly or in part by property owners, the cost may, at the request of such property owners, be assessed and spread over not more than five years against such abutting property owners and the cost shall be collected and treated in the same manner as taxes assessed under the general laws of the state. When such request is made, interest at a rate established from time to time by the township board, not exceeding the rate of eight percent per annum, shall be added to the amount spread on the tax rolls. 
(d)  Alternatively, the township board may require the owners of any lot or premises to build or repair the sidewalks within such time and in such manner as the township board may require, including before a building permit is issued for an improvement on the premises. If the owner shall fail to build or repair the sidewalks as ordered, the township board may cause such sidewalks to be built or repaired; and the expense thereof shall be assessed against such property owners. The expense shall be collected and treated in the same manner as taxes assessed under the general laws of the state. 
(Code 1986, § 4-02.05)  
Chapter 62 - SUBDIVISIONS AND OTHER DIVISIONS OF LAND[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Any ordinance dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat or subdivision saved from repeal, § 1-11(12); buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 26; floods, ch. 34; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; utilities, ch. 78; vegetation, ch. 82; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 62-162-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SUBDIVISIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 62-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alley means a public or private right-of-way shown on a plat which provides secondary access to a lot, block or parcel of land. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(z). 
Block means a city square, also the length of one side of such a square. 
Board means the board of county road commissioners. 
Board's specifications means the Requirements and Specifications for New Street Construction, dated December 27, 1967, as issued by the board of county road commissioners. 
Caption means the name by which the plat is legally and commonly known. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(t). 
Commission means the planning commission of the township. 
Comprehensive plan means the master plan or development plan which has been adopted by the planning commission as specified in Public Act No. 168 of 1959 (MCL 125.321 et seq.). 
Construction standards means standards and specifications of construction and installation as established and administered by the township or the county road commission. 
County plat board means the register of deeds, who shall act as chair, the county clerk who shall act as secretary, and the county treasurer. If the offices of county clerk and register of deeds have been combined, the chairman of the board of supervisors shall be a member of the plat board and shall act as chairman. In a county where a board of auditors is authorized by law such board may elect to serve on the county plat board by adopting a resolution so ordering. A copy of the recorded resolution shall be sent to the state treasurer. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(r). 
Cul-de-sac means a minor street with only one open end and with the other end being terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
Division means the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, or assigns for the purpose of sale, or lease of more than one year, or of building development that results in one or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent, and that satisfies the requirements of sections 108 and 109 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.108, 560.109). The term "division" does not include a property transfer between two or more adjacent parcels, if the property taken from one parcel is added to an adjacent parcel; and any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) or the requirements of applicable ordinance. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(f). 
Easement means a nonprofitable interest in land owned by another that entitles its holder to a specific limited public or private use. 
Floodplain means that area of land adjoining the channel of a river, stream, watercourse, lake or other similar body of water which will be inundated by a flood which can reasonably be expected for that region. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(ee). 
Governing body means the township board. 
Government survey means the land surveyed, subdivided and monumented by the United States Public Land Survey. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(x). 
Health department means the state department of environmental quality, a city, county or district health department having jurisdiction. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(aa). 
Improvements means street construction and surfacing, curb and gutter, water mains, storm and sanitary sewers, sidewalks, walkways, graded outlawns and bridges or culverts. 
Land means all land areas occupied by real property. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(b). 
Lot means a measured portion of a parcel or tract of land which is described and fixed in a recorded plat. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(m). 
Major street and thoroughfare plan means the master plan of highways, major streets and parkways adopted by the planning commission. 
Michigan Coordinate System means the system defined in Public Act No. 9 of 1964 (MCL 54.231 et seq.). 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(y). 
Municipality means the township. 
Outlot (when included within the boundary of a recorded plat) means a lot set aside for purposes other than a building site, park, or other land dedicated to public use or reserved to private use. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(n). 
Parcel means a continuous area or acreage of land which can be described as provided for in this article. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(g). 
Planner means the planning consultant, planning director, building inspector, township clerk or any person designated to administer this article. 
Plat means a map or chart of a subdivision of land. 
(1)  Preliminary plat means a map showing salient features of a proposed subdivision submitted to an approving authority for purposes of preliminary consideration. 
(2)  Final plat means an instrument by which the subdivision is recorded. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(a), (c). 
Proprietor means a natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation or combination of any of them which may hold any ownership interest in land whether recorded or not. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(o). 
Public sewer means a sewerage system as defined in section 4101 of Public Act No. 450 of 1994 (MCL 324.4101). 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(bb). 
Public utility means all persons, firms, corporations, copartnerships or municipal or other public authority providing gas, electricity, water, steam, telephone, sewer or other services of a similar nature. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(s). 
Public water means a system of pipes and structures through which water is obtained and distributed to the public, including wells and well structures, intakes, and cribs, pumping stations, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used or intended for use for the purpose of furnishing water to the public for household or drinking purposes. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(cc). 
Replat means the process of changing, or the map or plat which changes, the boundaries of a recorded subdivision plat or part thereof. The legal dividing of an outlot within a recorded subdivision plat without changing the exterior boundaries of the outlot is not a replat. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(u). 
School board means the board of education or legislative body of the local school district. 
School, superintendent, means the administrative head for the local school district. 
Street means a way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, throughway, road, avenue, drive, boulevard, lane, place, court or however otherwise designated. 
(1)  Arterial street. A street which is used primarily for high volume and high speed traffic and designated as arterial in the comprehensive plan. 
(2)  Collector street. A street which carries traffic from minor streets to the major system of arterial streets and highways, including the principal entrance streets of residential development and streets for circulation within such a development. 
(3)  Minor street. A street which is used primarily for access to the abutting properties. 
Subdivider means a natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation, or a combination of any of them, intending to subdivide land as defined and controlled by this article. 
Surveyor means either a land surveyor who is registered in the state as a registered land surveyor or a civil engineer who is registered in the state as a registered professional engineer licensed under article 20 of the Occupation Code (MCL 339.2001 et seq.). 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(v). 
Topographical map means a map showing existing physical characteristics, with contour lines at sufficient intervals to permit determination of proposed grades and drainage. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(dd). 
Township engineer and engineer mean the resident or consulting engineer designated as the official engineer for the township. 
Walkway means a public or private right-of-way across a block to be used by pedestrians and/or for underground utilities and located so as to connect two or more streets or a street and a public land parcel. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.02) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 62-32. - Scope. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to any lot or lots forming a part of a subdivision created and recorded prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived nor is it intended by this article to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way impair or interfere: 
(1)  With existing provisions of other laws or ordinances, except those specifically repealed by this article; 
(2)  With private restrictions placed upon property by deed, covenant or other private agreement; or 
(3)  With restrictive covenants running with the land to which the township is a party. 
(b)  Where this article imposes a greater restriction upon land than is imposed or required by such existing provisions of law, ordinance, contract or deed, the provisions of this article shall control. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.03)  
Sec. 62-33. - Amendments. 
The governing body may, by ordinance, amend, supplement or change this article; provided that prior to such amendment, a public hearing is held by both the commission and the governing body after giving notice of hearing at least 15 days prior to the date of hearing, by publication in an official paper of general circulation in the township and by United States mail to each public utility company and railroad company within the township. A copy of such amendment, supplement or change shall be filed with the county register of deeds. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.08)  
Sec. 62-34. - Variances. 
(a)  For hardship or because impracticable. 
(1)  The township planning commission may recommend to the township board a variance from the provisions of this article on a finding that undue hardship may result from strict compliance with specific provisions or requirements of the article or that application of such provision or requirement is impracticable. 
(2)  The planning commission shall only recommend variances that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. 
(3)  In making its findings, as required in this section, the planning commission shall take into account: 
a.  The nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity; 
b.  The number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision; and 
c.  The probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. 
(4)  No variance shall be recommended unless the planning commission finds after a public hearing: 
a.  That there are such special circumstances or conditions affecting such property that the strict application of the provisions of this article would clearly be impracticable or unreasonable. In such cases the subdivider shall first state his reasons in writing as to the specific provision or requirement involved and submit them to the planning commission. 
b.  That the granting of the specified variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the area in which such property is situated. 
c.  That such variance will not violate the provisions of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
d.  That such variance will not have the effect of nullifying the interest and purpose of this article and the comprehensive development plan of the township. 
(5)  The planning commission shall include its findings and the specific reasons therefore in its report of recommendations to the township board and shall also record its reasons and actions in its minutes. 
(b)  Topographical-physical limitation. Where in the case of a particular proposed subdivision, it can be shown that strict compliance with the requirements of this article would result in extraordinary hardship to the subdivider because of unusual topography, other physical conditions, or other such conditions which are not self-inflicted, or that these conditions would result in inhibiting the achievement of the objectives of this article, the planning commission may recommend to the township board that variance modification or a waiver of these requirements be granted. 
(c)  Planned unit development. The developer may request a variance from specified portions of this article in the case of a planned unit development. 
(1)  Considerations. The planning commission shall take into account: 
a.  The nature of the proposed use of land and existing use of land in the vicinity; 
b.  The number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision; and 
c.  The probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. 
(2)  Findings. If in the judgment of the planning commission such a plan provides adequate public spaces and includes provisions for efficient circulation, light and air and other needs, it shall make findings, as required in this section. The planning commission shall report to the township board whether: 
a.  The proposed project will constitute a desirable and stable community development. 
b.  The proposed project will be in harmony with adjacent areas. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.09)  
Sec. 62-35. - No building permit issued. 
The township building official shall not issue a building permit for any building to be constructed on land subdivided in violation of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.10)  
Secs. 62-3662-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PLATTING 
 
Sec. 62-51. - Required. 
No subdivider proposing to subdivide land within the limits of the township to which these regulations are applicable, shall enter into any contract for the sale of any of the proposed lots until he has obtained from the commission, the board and the governing body approval of the preliminary and final plat of the proposed subdivision. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.04.01)  
Sec. 62-52. - Preliminary plat specifications and approval. 
(a)  Specifications. The preliminary plat shall be filed with the township clerk in conformity with the requirements and specifications as set forth in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), the board's specifications and the following: 
(1)  The plan shall be drawn to a scale not greater than 200 feet to one inch. 
(2)  The existing development, including officially platted or dedicated streets within areas adjacent to the proposed plat shall be shown on the plan. 
(3)  Date and north points shall be shown. 
(4)  Locations and pertinent dimensions of proposed lots and parks. 
(5)  The location, size and essential invert elevations of the nearest available public sanitary and storm sewers and water main, existing and proposed, shall be shown. If no sanitary sewer is available and the subdivider proposes the use of individual systems for water supply and/or sewage disposal, the systems shall conform to the requirements as set forth by the county department of health. 
(6)  The proposed numbers of lots shall be shown by numerical order commencing with number "1" and with no omissions or duplications. 
(7)  There shall be no block numbers or letters. 
(8)  Type and width of proposed roadway construction shall be shown. 
(9)  A written statement of intent and what action has been taken relative to the installation of utilities and roadway construction shall be furnished. 
(10)  When the proposed plat includes only a portion of the subdivider's total tract of land, there shall be shown in sketch form the proposed development for the remaining portion of such tract proposed to be subdivided in the future. 
(b)  Approval by commission. 
(1)  Upon receipt of the preliminary plat from the governing body, the planning commission shall review such plat for the purpose of checking its compliance with the comprehensive plan, major street and thoroughfare plan and other specifications of this article, the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and the board's specifications. 
(2)  Before acting on the preliminary plat, the commission shall hold a public hearing, notice of which shall contain the date and place of hearing, and shall be sent by United States mail to the subdivider and owners of unplatted land of five acres or more immediately adjacent to the proposed subdivision at least seven days prior to the hearing date. 
(3)  Recommendations of approval of the preliminary plat shall be submitted to the governing body for their consideration. Written approval by the commission shall be indicated on the preliminary plat along with any changes or requirements that the commission may make, constituting acceptance thereof as a basis for the preparation of the final plat. 
(Code 1986, §§ 4-01.04.02, 4-01.04.03) 
State Law reference Preliminary plats, MCL 560.105 et seq.  
Sec. 62-53. - Final plat specifications and approval. 
(a)  Specifications. The final plat shall be filed with the township clerk in compliance with the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), the board's specifications, and the following: 
(1)  Water and sewers feasible and adequate. A statement by the township engineer that the proposed water mains, sanitary sewers and combined sewers, as shown on the preliminary plat, are feasible and adequate to serve the proposed lots and that they conform to the general plan of the district. 
(2)  Financial assurance for sanitary sewers. Proof of cash deposit or other financial assurance acceptable to the governing body, in the amount of the township engineer's estimated cost for sanitary sewer construction in accordance with section 62-97. 
(3)  Financial assurance for water mains. Proof of a cash deposit or other financial assurance acceptable to the governing body, in the amount of the township engineer's estimated cost for water main construction in accordance with section 62-97. 
(4)  County drain commission sewer petition. Proof that a petition has been processed by the county drain commission to construct storm sewers in proposed plats where sanitary sewers are available or combined sewers in proposed plats located within combined sewer districts. 
(5)  Plat restrictions. Plat restrictions, if such are proposed by the subdivider, shall be submitted with the final record plat. These restrictions shall become a part of the final record plat and shall be recorded along with the plat in the office of the county register of deeds. 
(b)  Security to insure improvements complete. In lieu of making improvements, the subdivider may, prior to final approval of the plat, provide a cash deposit, certified check or surety bond, or an irrevocable letter of credit drawn on a form generally acceptable and by a financial institution familiar to the governing body, whichever security the proprietor selects, to insure the completion of such improvements. 
(c)  Approval. 
(1)  Final record plat approval will be granted only under the following conditions: 
a.  That the subdivider has submitted through the governing body the final record plat, being one lithoprint thereof. 
b.  That the subdivider has submitted through the governing body necessary engineering drawings, as required by this article, and such drawings have been checked and approved for engineering accuracy by the township engineer. 
c.  That the subdivider has installed all improvements, or in lieu thereof, has made arrangements for the installation of such improvements in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  After final approval, the commission shall submit recommendations of approval, along with the necessary agreements, restrictions and fees, as required in this article, and the final lithoprint to the governing body. 
(3)  Upon receipt of the approval of the final plat and other material from the planning commission, the governing body shall take action upon such plat in accordance with the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), the board's specifications, this article and any other township Code provisions or regulations. 
(4)  In case of disapproval, the reasons for such action shall, by written communication, be transmitted to the subdivider and the commission. Both the subdivider and the commission shall, within a reasonable time, resubmit to the governing body any changes or alterations stipulated in the governing body's action of disapproval. 
(5)  Upon approval of the final plat, the township clerk shall, in accordance with the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), the board's specifications and any other applicable requirements, file such lithoprint, agreements, restrictions and fees with the county clerk. 
(Code 1986, §§ 4-01.04.04, 4-01.04.05) 
State Law reference Final plats, MCL 560.105, 560.133 et seq.; authority to require bond, MCL 560.188(2).  
Secs. 62-5462-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 62-71. - Generally. 
Specifications and standards for subdivisions shall be in conformity with the provisions as set forth in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and this division. Requirements and specifications not specifically stipulated in this article shall comply with the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and the board's specifications. 
(Code 1986, §§ 4-01.06.01, 4-01.06.04(E))  
Sec. 62-72. - Variations and exceptions. 
In cases where variations and exceptions from the dimensional standards, improvement requirements and open space requirements are deemed necessary due to unusual physical conditions or new design techniques, such variations shall be considered by the commission and appropriate recommendations made to the governing body in accord with the provision of section 62-34. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.06.04(B))  
Sec. 62-73. - Acquisition of open space for public use. 
When held appropriate by the commission, open spaces suitably located and of adequate size for parks or other public use shall be made available for acquisition by the township. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.06.04(A))  
Sec. 62-74. - Dedicated ingress and egress. 
Every subdivision shall have dedicated means of ingress and egress. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.06.04(C))  
Sec. 62-75. - Streets and alleys. 
(a)  Generally. The subdivision of land or the dedication of land for streets, alleys, highways, parks or other public uses shall conform to the major street and thoroughfare plan and comprehensive plan. 
(b)  Location and arrangement. 
(1)  In the preparation of new subdivision, provisions shall be made for the continuation of existing or platted streets in adjoining or adjacent subdivisions or parcels of land, insofar as they may be necessary for public requirements. The centerlines of such streets shall continue with the centerlines of existing streets. 
(2)  In general, the streets shall extend to the boundary of the subdivision to provide for proper connection with the street system for contiguous and adjacent land. 
(3)  Contours, when required by the commission or if topography dictates, shall be provided. 
(4)  If there exists a dedicated and recorded one-half street on an adjoining plat, the other one-half must be dedicated on the proposed plat to make the street complete.
