(c)  Right-of-way widths. Minimum right-of-way widths shall be as follows: 
(1)  Arterial, collector, parkways, and local. Major arterial, collector streets, parkways, and local streets, in accordance with the minimum requirements as set forth in the adopted rules and regulations known as requirements and specifications for new street construction of the board of county road commissioners, effective January 1, 1968, and any amendments thereof, or as may be otherwise required by the term of the major street plan adopted by the township board upon the advice of the township planning commission. 
(2)  Alleys and service drives. For alleys and service drives the minimum right-of-way width shall be 40 feet. 
(3)  Walkways. For walkways the minimum right-of-way width shall be ten feet. 
(4)  Culs-de-sac. Width of right-of-way and roadway design for culs-de-sac shall be in accordance with requirements and specifications for new street construction of the board of county road commissioners. The length of a cul-de-sac street shall not exceed an overall developed length of 700 feet. The length shall be measured starting at a point where the centerline of the cul-de-sac street intersects the centerline of the nearest intersecting street to the center point of the circular portion of the street as shown in the drawing below. 
 
Cul-de-sac Streets 
A cul-de-sac street may have either a circular or elliptical dimension, but in no case shall any radius exceed 700 feet. 
(d)  Alleys in residential districts. Alleys shall not be accepted in residential districts unless specifically required by the commission. 
(e)  Street names. Street names shall not be the same as any other street name presently existing in the county. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.06.01) 
Cross reference Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58.  
Sec. 62-76. - Blocks. 
(a)  Length. No block shall be more than 1,320 feet in length except along major roads. 
(b)  Easements. In blocks 900 feet in length the commission may require an easement for public utilities at or near the middle of the block. 
(c)  Intersecting streets. The number of intersecting streets along highways and major streets shall be held to a minimum. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.06.02)  
Sec. 62-77. - Lots. 
(a)  Accessible to a public street. All lots shall have access to a public street. 
(b)  Side lot lines. The side lines of lots shall be approximately radial or perpendicular to the street upon which the lots face. 
(c)  Corporate boundary lines. No lot shall be divided by a corporate boundary line. Such boundary line may be the lot line or centerline of streets or alleys. 
(d)  Widths, depths, and area. Lot widths, depths and area shall conform to the stipulations as set forth in the zoning ordinance. 
(e)  Corner lot width. Corner lots shall be of sufficient width to allow conformance with building lines as established in the zoning ordinance. 
(f)  Restrictive covenant. Where lots are developed so that they abut an arterial street, highway or parkway and are provided with an alternate means of access, when practicable the subdivider shall record with the county register of deeds, a restrictive covenant running with the land providing that no right to access by vehicular traffic to the arterial street, highway or parkway is permitted from or onto such lots. 
(g)  Partitioning or dividing. An existing lot may be partitioned or divided where each of the resulting parcels is to be developed or used in conjunction with an immediately contiguous lot as a single building site. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.06.03)  
Sec. 62-78. - Adequate water or sewage disposal. 
No plat shall be approved where inadequate water supply, or sewage disposal conditions exist. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.06.04(D)) 
Cross reference Utilities, ch. 78.  
Secs. 62-7962-95. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Improvements, MCL 560.188. 
 
Sec. 62-96. - Compliance. 
Improvements shall be installed in conformity with the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), the board's specifications and as provided in this division. The minimum improvements which shall be installed according to the township construction standards are as provided in this division. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01)  
Sec. 62-97. - Financing. 
The financing of the installation of road and street construction (including storm sewer and drainage facilities) shall be accomplished in accordance with the provisions set forth in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), the board's specifications and for other improvements as follows: 
(1)  Water mains and sanitary sewers. 
a.  In areas where water mains are available within a distance of 500 feet of a proposed plat, the subdivider shall deposit with the township treasurer, the estimated cost as determined by the township engineer of the water mains required to serve the lots in such plat; provided however, that the estimated cost shall not include the additional cost of water mains larger than six inches in diameter. 
b.  In areas where sanitary sewers are available within a distance of 500 feet of a proposed plat, the subdivider shall deposit with the township treasurer, the larger of the estimated costs as determined by the township engineer, of the sanitary sewers required to serve the lots in such plat or an amount equal to the number of lots times unit assessment for the district in which the property is located less the amount of previous assessments against the property; provided, however, that the estimated cost shall not include the additional cost of sewer mains larger than eight inches in diameter. 
c.  When water mains larger than six inches and sewer mains larger than eight inches are required and water and sewer lines have to be extended to the plat, the additional cost will be payable from township funds. 
d.  Upon receipt of deposit for the cost of sanitary sewer and water mains, the governing body shall order construction plans, receive bids, award contracts and have such utilities installed as soon as possible. 
e.  When construction is completed, the final accounting of the funds deposited will be made with the subdivider. 
f.  The subdivider may request, by petition of the governing body, the installation of the improvements required by the subdivider, wherein the governing body may install all or any of the required improvements, and assess the subdivider for such improvements costs, under conditions which the governing body may determine. 
(2)  Combined sewer districts. 
a.  When proposed subdivisions are located in a combination sewer district, the subdivider shall petition the county drain commission to construct the required combination sewers to serve the subdivision, in accordance with the Drain Code of 1956 (MCL 280.1 et seq.). A copy of such petition approved by the drain commission shall be filed with the planning commission at the time the final plat is submitted for approval. 
b.  When such subdivision is in an incorporated area, a petition for the construction of combined sewers shall be filed with the governing body. 
(3)  Pavements and storm drainage. 
a.  Pavements and storm drainage in subdivisions under the jurisdiction of the board of county road commissioners shall be constructed in accordance with the rules and regulations of the board of county road commissioners; provided however, that the improvements required by this article for curb, gutter, pavement type and width, shall be the minimum requirements. 
b.  In subdivisions not under the jurisdiction of the board of county road commissioners arrangements shall be made with the township in the same manner as for sanitary sewers and water mains. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.02)  
Sec. 62-98. - Streets and roads. 
(a)  Subdivisions with sanitary sewers. In subdivisions where sanitary sewers are available a street shall be constructed with curb and gutter on both sides of the street and hard surfaced at the permanently established elevation to the width specified in this division, of which the subdivider shall pay 100 percent of the labor and materials needed for the installation. 
(b)  Subdivisions with no sanitary sewers. In subdivisions where no sanitary sewer is available, a hard surface street shall be provided at the permanently established elevation, to the width specified in this division, of which the subdivider shall pay 100 percent of the labor and materials needed for the installation. 
(c)  Roadway construction. Roadway construction shall be in accordance with requirements and specifications for new street construction of the board of county road commissioners. Exception: If sanitary sewer is not available, the street surface may be installed without curb and gutter. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(A)) 
Cross reference Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58.  
Sec. 62-99. - Culverts and bridges. 
Culverts and bridges shall be constructed when determined to be necessary by the township official having jurisdiction. The subdivider shall pay 100 percent of the labor and materials needed to construct such culvert and/or bridge. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(B))  
Sec. 62-100. - Sanitary sewer lines. 
Sanitary sewer lines shall be installed, when an adequate sanitary sewer main exists within 500 feet by way of an easement from any portion of the proposed subdivision, of which the subdivider shall pay 100 percent of the labor and materials needed for the installation of up to and including eight-inch-diameter sewer mains within the subdivision being platted. Sanitary sewer line shall include service connection from the sewer main to the property line. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(C)) 
Cross reference Utilities, ch. 78.  
Sec. 62-101. - Water lines. 
(a)  In easements by subdivider. Water lines shall be installed in all proposed subdivisions by way of an easement of which the subdivider shall pay 100 percent of the labor and materials needed for the installation of such water line. 
(b)  Size. The township engineer shall determine the size for all new water mains. In residential areas, the size shall be eight-inch diameter with the minimum size being six-inch for hydrant leads. In commercial, industrial, or high density residential areas, the distribution lines shall be 12-inch diameter. 
(c)  Hydrants. Hydrants shall be provided at all intersections within all plats. In residential areas, hydrants shall have a maximum spacing of 550 feet. Hydrant spacing in commercial, industrial, or high density residential areas shall not exceed 300 feet. All hydrants will be considered as part of the township water supply and easements shall be provided along the main and hydrant lead for access, repair, and/or replacement. 
(d)  Looping requirement. All water mains shall be looped at the developer's expense. Exceptions from the looping requirement may be granted on appeal to the township board at a public hearing only upon the recommendation of the township engineer, fire chief, and director of public services. An appeal may be granted only if sufficient water service and fire protection can be provided, and there is a physical obstacle preventing the loop that cannot be overcome. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(D))  
Sec. 62-102. - Wells and sewage disposal fields. 
If no municipal water supply is available, the subdivider shall record with the county register of deeds at the time of recording the plat and furnishing proof of such recording to the township, a restrictive covenant running with the land. The restrictive covenant shall provide that all owners of any land in the plat shall follow the recommendations of the county health department when establishing the location of wells and sewage disposal fields. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(E))  
Sec. 62-103. - Storm sewer lines. 
Storm sewer lines, including catchbasins and manholes, shall be installed in accordance with the adopted rules and regulations of the county drain commissioner. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(F))  
Sec. 62-104. - Rear lot provisions. 
(a)  Utility easement. A utility easement shall be provided in the plat over the rear ten feet of each lot. 
(b)  Storm drainage. Rear lot storm drainage shall be provided as approved by the township engineer. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(G))  
Sec. 62-105. - Sidewalks. 
Sidewalks shall be constructed in such places as are provided for in chapter 58, article II of this Code. The subdivider shall deposit with the township treasurer such sum, letter of credit, or performance bond to cover the cost of construction of the sidewalk in such amount as determined by the township engineer and shall pay for and/or install such sidewalk. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(H))  
Sec. 62-106. - Removal and replacement of monuments. 
If, during the process of the installation of improvements, it is deemed necessary to remove any monuments or benchmarks, the subdivider or his contractor shall obtain permission from the township engineer to make such removal. All monuments or benchmarks removed, relocated or destroyed shall be replaced in their proper location, by the subdivider, at his expense. 
(Code 1986, § 4-01.07.01(I))  
Secs. 62-10762-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LAND DIVISIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference Zoning, app. A. 
 
Sec. 62-141. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrator means the township zoning administrator. 
Applicant and proprietor mean a natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation, or combination of any of them that holds an ownership interest in land whether recorded or not. 
Divided and division mean the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, or assigns for the purpose of sale, or lease of more than one year, or of building development that results in one or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent, and that satisfies the requirements of sections 108 and 109 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.108, 560.109). The term "division" does not include a property transfer between two or more adjacent parcels, if the property taken from one parcel is added to an adjacent parcel; and any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) or the requirements of applicable ordinance. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(d). 
Exempt split and exempt division mean the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, or assigns that does not result in one or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent. For a property transfer between two or more adjacent parcels, if the property taken from one parcel is added to an adjacent parcel, any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) or the requirements of applicable ordinance. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(e). 
Forty acres or the equivalent means either 40 acres, a quarter-quarter section containing not less than 30 acres, or government lot containing not less than 30 acres. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(l). 
Governing body means the township board. 
Land division committee means the committee designed to review all property divisions that occur within the township. This committee is comprised of the township assessor and zoning administrator. 
Parcel means a contiguous area or acreage of land which can be described as provided for in section 102(g) of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.102(g)). 
Parent parcel and parent tract mean a parcel or tract, respectively, lawfully in existence on March 31, 1997. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(i). 
Resulting parcel means one or more parcels which result from a land division. 
Road authority means the governmental authority having jurisdiction over a public road or public street. 
Tract means two or more parcels that share a common property line and are under the same ownership. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 560.102(h). 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.02, 1-12-1999) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 62-142. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this article is to carry out the provisions of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), to prevent the creation of parcels of property which do not comply with applicable township ordinances and such Act, to minimize potential boundary disputes, to maintain orderly development of the community, and otherwise provide for the health, safety and welfare of the residents and property owners of the municipality by establishing reasonable standards for prior review and approval of land divisions within the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.01, 1-12-1999)  
Sec. 62-143. - Prior approval requirement for land divisions. 
Land within the township shall not be divided without the prior review and approval of the Land Division Committee, in accordance with this article and the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.); provided that the following shall be exempted from this requirement: 
(1)  A parcel proposed for subdivision through a recorded plat pursuant to article II of this chapter and the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(2)  A parcel proposed for site condominiums pursuant to any township condominium ordinance or the Condominium Act (MCL 559.101 et seq.) and the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(3)  A lot in a recorded plat proposed to be divided in accordance with article II of this chapter and the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(4)  An exempt split as defined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.03, 1-12-1999)  
Sec. 62-144. - Application for land division approval. 
(a)  An applicant shall file all of the following information with the township assessor for review and approval of a proposed land division before making any division either by deed, land contract, lease for more than one year, or for building development: 
(1)  A completed application on such written form as the township may provide, including any exhibits described therein. 
(2)  Proof of fee ownership of the land proposed to be divided or written consent to the application, signed by the owner of such land. 
(3)  A copy of each deed or other instrument of conveyance which contains the statements required by sections 109(3) and 109(4) of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.109(3),560.109(4)) as outlined as follows: 
a.  Assignment of division rights. If transfer of division rights are proposed in the land transfer, detailed information about the terms and availability of the proposed division rights transfer is mandatory and must be outlined in the deed. A statement shall be in substantially the following form: "The grantor grants to the grantee the right to make (insert number) divisions(s) under section 108 of the Land Division Act, Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of 1967." 
b.  Right to farm act. All deeds for parcels of unplatted land must contain the following statement, regardless of whether the parcel is located in a downtown metropolitan area or in a remote region of the state. "This property may be located within the vicinity of farmland or a farm operation. Generally accepted agricultural and management practices which may generate noise, dust, odors, and other associated conditions may be used and are protected by the Michigan right to farm act." 
(4)  A survey map of the land proposed to be divided, prepared pursuant to the survey map requirements of Public Act No. 132 of 1970 (MCL 54.211 et seq.) by a land surveyor licensed by the state. The survey map shall include: 
a.  The dimensions and legal descriptions of the existing parcel and the parcels proposed to be created by the division; 
b.  The location of all existing structures and other land improvements; 
c.  The accessibility of the parcels for vehicular traffic and utilities from existing public roads. 
(5)  In lieu of such survey map, at the applicant's option, the applicant may waive the 45-day statutory requirement for a decision on the application until such survey map and legal description are filed with the township assessor. In order to take advantage of this requirement, the applicant shall submit a tentative preliminary parcel map drawn to scale on not less than that provided for on the application form, for preliminary approval, and/or denial by the land division committee prior to a final application under this section. The preliminary parcel map shall depict: 
a.  An accurate legal description of each proposed division; 
b.  The boundary lines and dimensions of each proposed division; 
c.  The accessibility of each division from existing or proposed public roads for vehicular traffic and public utilities. 
(6)  Proof that all standards of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and this article have been met. (See the checklist accompanying the ordinance from which this article is derived). 
(7)  The history and specifications of any previous divisions of land of which the proposed division was part of which is sufficient to establish the parcel to be divided was lawfully in existence as of March 31, 1997, the effective date of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(8)  Proof that all due and payable taxes or installments of special assessments and deferred assessments pertaining to the land proposed to be divided are paid in full. 
(b)  Unless a division creates a parcel which is acknowledged and declared to be "not buildable" under section 62-147, all divisions shall result in "buildable" parcels containing sufficient "buildable area outside of unbuildable wetlands, floodplains and other areas where buildings are prohibited therefrom, and with sufficient area to comply with all required setback provisions, minimum floor areas, off-street parking spaces, on-site sewage disposal and water well locations (where public water and sewer service is not available), and maximum allowed area coverage of buildings and structures on the site. 
(c)  A fee may be established by resolution of the township board for land division reviews pursuant to this article to cover the costs of review of the application and administration of this article. 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.04, 1-12-1999)  
Sec. 62-145. - Procedure for review of applications for land division approval. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the land division application package, the township assessor shall meet with the township zoning administrator to either: 
(1)  Approve; 
(2)  Approve with reasonable conditions to assure compliance with applicable ordinances and the protection of public health, safety and general welfare; or 
(3)  Disapprove the land division. 
(b)  Such action must take place within 45 days of a complete submittal of the land division application package conforming to the requirements of this article. The administrator shall promptly notify the applicant of the decision and the reasons for any denial. If the application package does not conform to the requirements of this article and the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), the administrator shall return the application package to the applicant for completion and refilling in accordance with this article and the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(c)  Any person or entity aggrieved by the decision of the land division committee may, within 30 days of such decision, file a written appeal to the township manager or such other board or person designated by the township board which shall consider and resolve such appeal by a majority vote of such board at its next regular meeting or session or by the designee. At least ten days' written notice of the date, time and place of the meeting at which the appeal is to be considered shall be given to the applicant by regular, first class mail, directed to the applicant's address as shown in the application or in the written appeal. The township manager or other board or person designated by the township board may affirm or reverse the decision of the land division committee, in whole or in part, and its decision shall be final. 
(d)  A decision approving a land division is effective for 90 days, after which it shall be considered revoked unless within such period a document is recorded with the county register of deeds office and filed with the township assessor accomplishing the approved land division or transfer. 
(e)  Any notice of approval for a resulting parcel of less than one acre in size shall contain a statement that the township is not liable if a building permit is not issued for the parcel for the reason that the parcel fails to satisfy the requirements of section 109a of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.109a), including approval of on-site water supply and on-site sewage disposal under the standards set forth in section 105(g) of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.105(g)). 
(f)  The township assessor shall maintain an official record of all approved and accomplished land divisions or transfers. 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.05, 1-12-1999)  
Sec. 62-146. - Standards for approval of land divisions. 
A proposed land division shall be approved if the following criteria are met: 
(1)  The proposed land division complies with all requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and this article. 
(2)  All the parcels to be created by the proposed land divisions fully comply with the applicable lot (parcel), yard and area requirements of the applicable zoning ordinance, including, but not limited to, minimum lot (parcel) frontage/width, minimum road frontage, minimum lot (parcel) coverage and minimum setbacks for existing buildings/structures. 
(3)  All parcels created and remaining have existing adequate accessibility, or an area available therefor, to a public road for public utilities and emergency and other vehicles not less than the requirements of the applicable zoning ordinance, major thoroughfare plan, road ordinance or this article. In determining adequacy of accessibility, any ordinance standards applicable to plats shall also apply as a minimum standard whenever a parcel or tract is proposed to be divided to create four or more parcels. 
(4)  The ratio of depth to width of any parcel created by a division which is ten acres or less in size can not exceed four to one (4:1), exclusive of access roads or easements. A property transfer between two or more contiguous parcels must also comply with the 4:1 lot depth to width ratio. Width shall be measured by using the road frontage. If the width of the parcel is irregular, the average width of the parcel shall be calculated and used for purposes of this provision. 
a.  The permissible depth of a parcel created by a land division shall be measured within the boundaries of each parcel from the abutting road right-of-way to the most remote boundary line point of the parcel from the point of commencement of the measurement. 
b.  The permissible minimum width shall be as defined in the applicable zoning ordinance. 
c.  The depth to width ratio requirements of this article do not apply to: 
1.  A parcel larger than ten acres, unless such parcel is zoned A-2, agriculture. 
2.  The remainder of the parent parcel or parent tract when it is retained by the proprietor. 
d.  The land division committee may allow a depth to width ratio of greater than four to one if failure to allow a greater depth to width ratio would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship. Such practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship may consist of, but is not limited to, exceptional topographic or physical conditions with respect to the parcel and compatibility with surrounding lands. 
(5)  Where accessibility is to be provided by a proposed new dedicated public road, proof that the county road commission or the state department of transportation has approved the proposed layout and construction design of the road and of utility easements and drainage facilities connected therewith. 
(6)  The number of parcels to be created by division must not exceed the number of parcels allowed by section 108 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.108). 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.06, 1-12-1999)  
Sec. 62-147. - Allowance for approval of other land divisions. 
Notwithstanding disqualification from approval pursuant to this article, a proposed land division which does not fully comply with the applicable lot, yard, accessibility and area requirements of the applicable zoning ordinance or this article may be approved in any of the following circumstances are present: 
(1)  Where the applicant executes and records an affidavit or deed restriction with the county register of deeds, in a form acceptable to the township, designating the parcel as "not buildable." Any such parcel shall also be designated as "not buildable" in the township records, and shall not thereafter by the subject of a request to the township zoning board of appeals for variance relief from the applicable lot and/or area requirements, and shall not be developed with any building or above ground structure. 
(2)  Where the zoning board of appeals has, previous to this article, granted a variance from the lot, yard, ratio, frontage and/or area requirements with which the parcel failed to comply. 
(3)  Where the proposed land division involves only the minor adjustment of a common boundary line or involves a conveyance between adjoining properties which does not result in either parcel violating this article, any applicable zoning ordinance, or Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.07, 1-12-1999)  
Sec. 62-148. - Consequences of noncompliance with land division approval requirement. 
Any parcel created in noncompliance with this article shall not be eligible for any building permits, or zoning approvals, such as special land use approval or site plan approval, and shall not be recognized as a separate parcel on the assessment roll. In addition, violation of this article shall subject the violator to the penalties and enforcement actions set forth in section 62-149, and as may otherwise be provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.08, 1-12-1999)  
Sec. 62-149. - Penalties and enforcement. 
Any person or other entity who violates any of the provisions of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction and subject to a civil fine of not more than $500.00 plus costs, which may include all direct or indirect expenses, to which the township has been put in connection with the violation. A violator of this article shall also be subject to such additional sanctions, remedies, and judicial orders as are authorized under state law. Each day a violation of this article continues to exist constitutes a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 612, § 4-05.09, 1-12-1999)  
Chapter 66 - TAXATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 66-1. - Property tax administration fee. 
On all tax sums voluntarily paid before February 15 of the succeeding year, the township treasurer shall add one percent for a property tax administration fee. 
(Code 1986, § 1-06.03) 
State Law reference Property tax administration fee, MCL 211.44(3).  
Sec. 66-2. - Late penalty charge. 
On all taxes paid after February 14 and before March 1, the township treasurer shall add to the tax a one percent property tax administration fee and a late penalty charge equal to three percent of such tax. 
(Code 1986, § 1-06.04) 
State Law reference Late penalty charge and property tax administration fee, MCL 211.44(3).  
Secs. 66-366-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TAX EXEMPTIONS AND ADMINISTRATIVE FEES IN LIEU THEREOF 
 
Sec. 66-31. - Housing project tax exemption eliminated. 
(a)  The tax exemption provided for in section 15a(1) of the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (MCL 125.1415(1) for a housing project owned by a nonprofit housing corporation, consumer housing cooperative, limited dividend housing corporation, mobile home park corporation or mobile home park association financed with a federally-aided or authority-aided mortgage or advance or grant from the authority shall not apply to all or any class of housing project or projects constructed or operated after the effective date of Ordinance No. 619, adopted June 6, 2001, and such project or projects shall be subject to all ad valorem property taxes imposed by the state or by any political subdivision, public body, or taxing district located within the township as provided in section 15a(5) of such act (MCL 125.1415(5)). 
(b)  This section shall not affect the tax exemptions grants to any housing project approved prior to the effective date of Ordinance No. 619, adopted June 6, 2001. 
(Ord. No. 619, §§ 1-08.01, 1-08.02, 6-6-2001)  
Sec. 66-32. - Lakeside elderly housing project. 
(a)  In this section: 
Contract rents are as defined by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development in regulations promulgated pursuant to the United States Housing Act of 1937, as amended by the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. 
Elderly means those persons 62 years of age or older or who otherwise qualify pursuant to the rules and regulations or practices of the Department of Housing and Urban Development for residency in an elderly housing project. 
Elderly housing project means a specific parcel of property improved for rental to a low or moderate income individual which qualifies as an elderly housing project under the rules and regulations or standard practices of the Department of Housing and Urban Development to the extent it is occupied by the elderly or held for rental exclusively to the elderly, excluding one unit for a development manager or caretaker. 
HUD means the Department of Housing and Urban Development of the United States of America. 
Specified project means a housing development identified as Lakeside Limited Dividend Housing Association ("Lakeside") on certain property located in the township, more particularly described as follows: 
A parcel of land in the Northwest ¼ of the Southeast ¼ of Fractional Section 2, Township 12 North, Range 4 East, Saginaw Township, Saginaw County, Michigan, described as follows: Commencing on the North and South ¼ line of said Section 2 at a point 1,728.03 feet, N. 00;deg; 22;min;19;sec; E., of the South ¼ corner of Section 2; thence N. 00;deg; 22;min; 19;sec; E., on said North and South ¼ line, 507.00 feet; thence S. 89;deg; 41;min; 07;sec; E., on a line which is parallel to and 2,235.03 feet, measured at right angles, North of the South line of said Section, 750.00 feet; thence S. 00;deg; 18;min; 53;sec; W., perpendicular to such South Section line, 396.00 feet; thence S. 36;deg; 16;min; 03;sec; W., 137.12 feet to a line which is parallel to and 1,728.03 feet, measured at right angles, North of the South line of Section 2; thence N. 89;deg; 41;min; 07;sec; W., on such line which is parallel to the South Section line, 670.00 feet to the point of beginning, containing 8.63 acres (375,910 square feet) of land and subject to highway use of the West 33 feet thereof. 
Sponsor means persons or entities which have applied to HUD for a mortgage loan insurance to finance an elderly housing project. 
Utilities means fuel, water, sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service which are paid by the project or tenants. 
(b)  It is hereby determined that the class of housing projects to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be elderly housing projects for elderly persons as defined in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  That portion of the specified project exclusively and especially designated for and occupied by elderly persons of low and moderate income developed and constructed upon a parcel of land within the township sufficient for the operation of such project (but no larger) shall be exempt from all property taxation beginning in the year following commencement of construction and continuing as long as: 
(1)  The mortgage loan insured by HUD remains outstanding and unpaid and as long as the HUD has any interest in such property; and 
(2)  The annual service charge is paid timely and all requirements of special use permit 78-02 to be issued are met. 
(d)  That portion of the specified project described in this section shall be subject to a service charge in lieu of such property taxes in an amount equal to four percent of 95 percent of contract rents of the preceding calendar year exclusive of utility charges paid by tenants and/or the project and the amount paid to the township during the preceding calendar year of the annual service charge. Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection, in no event shall the service charge, at any time, be less than the property taxes upon the subject property for the tax year prior to the date when construction was commenced. 
(e)  The service charge in lieu of taxes as determined under this section shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes are payable in the township except that the annual payment shall be paid on or before December 31 of each year. The entire tax collection procedure provided by the general property tax act shall be effective with respect to such payment including, but not by way of limitation, the provisions providing for interest and penalties on late payments, return of delinquent taxes, and the sale of lands for delinquent taxes. 
(Code 1986, §§ 1-04.031-04.07) 
State Law reference Authority for above, MCL 125.1415.  
Sec. 66-33. - South Colony elderly housing project. 
(a)  In this section: 
Authority means the state housing development authority. 
Mortgagor means a limited dividend housing association to be formed by Nathan Schafer and Associates. 
Project means the Saginaw Township Elderly Project MSHDA No. 514, to be constructed at 5285 Gratiot Road. 
(b)  Pursuant to Public Act No. 346 of 1966 (MCL 125.1401 et seq.), the township, acknowledging the reliance of the mortgagor and the authority on exemption of the project from all ad valorem property taxes, hereby exempts the project from all property taxes from and after commencement of construction of the project. The specific property and improvements thereon which is granted property tax exemption hereby is described as follows: 
All that portion of the following described property located North and West of South Colony Drive as extended, as finally accepted by the county road commission. 
A parcel of land in the North ½ of the Southeast ¼ of Section 29, T.12 N - R.4 E., Saginaw Township, Saginaw County, Michigan described as follows: Commencing on the East and West ¼ line of said Section at a point 1,321.99 feet, N. 89;deg; 33;min; 40;sec; W., of the East ¼ corner of Section 29; thence S. 00;deg; 03;min; 05;sec; W., on a line which is parallel to and 1,302.50 feet, measured parallel to the East and West ¼ line, East of the North and South ¼ line of said Section, 500.01 feet; thence S. 89;deg; 33;min; 40;sec; E., on a line which is parallel to and 500.00 feet, measured at right angles, South of said East and West ¼ line, 169.19 feet; thence S. 00;deg; 12;min; 00;sec; E., on a line which intersects said East and West ¼ line at a point 1,155.00 feet, N. 89;deg; 33;min; 40;sec; W., of said East ¼ corner and also intersects the Northwest corner of Stroebel Subdivision, 453.03 feet; thence N. 89;deg; 33;min; 40;sec; W., on a line which is parallel to and 953.00 feet, measured at right angles, South of said East and West ¼ line, 566.16 feet; thence N. 00;deg; 03;min; 05;sec; E., parallel to said North and South ¼ line, 800.02 feet to a point which is 153.00 feet S. 00;deg; 03;min; 05;sec; W., of said East and West ¼ line; thence S. 89;deg; 33;min; 40;sec; E., parallel to said East and West ¼ line, 110.00 feet; thence N. 00;deg; 03;min; 05;sec; E., parallel to said North and South ¼ line, 153.00 feet to a point on said East and West ¼ line which is 1,017.50 feet, S. 89;deg; 33;min; 40;sec; E., of the center post of said Section 29; thence S. 89;deg; 33;min; 40;sec; E., on said East and West ¼ line, 285.00 feet to the point of beginning, containing 10.02 acres of land and subject to an existing highway easement being that portion thereof which lies North of a line which is 60.00 feet, measured at right angles, South of the constructed centerline of Highway M-46 and also subject to an easement for the Seidel Drain. 
(c)  In consideration of the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section and on behalf of the township, the township hereby agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes in the amount equal to the greater of: 
(1)  The tax on the property on which the project is located for the tax year prior to the date when construction of the project was commenced; or 
(2)  Four percent of 95 percent of the contract rents (as defined by the rules pursuant to the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, as amended) of the preceding calendar year exclusive of utilities and the amount paid to the township during the preceding calendar year of the annual service charge, and in any event, such annual service charge shall not be less than the service charge provided by Public Act No. 346 of 1966 (MCL 125.1411 et seq.). 
(d)  This section shall remain in effect and shall not terminate: 
(1)  So long as the mortgage loan anticipated to be obtained from the authority remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the project; and 
(2)  So long as the annual service charge is paid timely and all requirements of special use permit 76-08 to be issued are met, including limitation of occupancy to senior citizens as defined by the township zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1986, §§ 1-03.021-03.05) 
State Law reference Authority for above, MCL 125.1415.  
Chapter 70 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; utilities, ch. 78; zoning, app. A. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 70-170-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CABLE TELEVISION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cable television means the business of transmission and distribution of television signals, including radio signals and other signals, or any other type of closed circuit transmission by means of electrical impulses, by means of cable to private subscribers and does not include the operation of a master television antenna system, the distribution system of which is confined to private property. 
Gross subscriber revenues means gross receipts from all revenues received by the permittee from subscribers located within the township including all revenues from cable service including premium service. The term "gross subscriber revenues" shall include revenues received by the permittee as charges for installations, reconnections and modifications of any installations, but not fees for inspections or repairs thereto. The term "gross subscriber revenues" shall not include unrelated business income and/or income received from the lease and/or sale of real or personal property, bad debts, deposits or refunds to subscribers and/or taxes on services furnished by the permittee imposed upon any subscriber by state, township, or other governmental unit and collected by the permittee on behalf of such governmental unit. 
Permittee means the holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.02) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-32. - Cablecasting commission. 
The township board may create a cablecasting commission, referred to in this article as the "commission" which will be composed of five members who serve for five-year staggered terms, the members to be appointed by the supervisor with the consent and approval of the township board. The township board may delegate to the commission such duties as it may from time to time deem necessary. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.08) 
Cross reference Boards and commissions, § 2-291 et seq.  
Sec. 70-33. - Conditions of street occupancy. 
(a)  Location. All transmission and distribution structures, lines and equipment erected by the permittee or on its behalf within the township shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with: 
(1)  The reasonable use of streets; and 
(2)  The rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of such streets. 
(b)  Restoration. In case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalk, driveway or other surfacing, the permittee shall, at its own cost and expense and in a manner approved by the township engineer, replace and restore all paving, sidewalk, driveway or surfacing of any street or alley disturbed, in as good condition as before such work was commenced. 
(c)  Relocation. If any time during the existence of a permit granted under this article the township shall lawfully widen, realign or otherwise alter the street right-of-way, or construct, reconstruct, realign, change the grade of or otherwise alter pavement of any water main, fire hydrant, sewer or appurtenance, the permittee and anyone acting for it in connection with the use of the streets, upon reasonable notice by the township, shall remove, relay and relocate its poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes and other fixtures at its own expense. 
(d)  Conduit districts. In areas of the township in which telephone lines and electric utility lines are underground, all permittees' lines, cables and wires shall be underground. 
(e)  Construction standards. The permittee's distribution system in the public streets shall comply with all applicable laws and regulations and Code provisions and all its wires and cables suspended from poles in the streets shall comply with the minimum clearances above ground required for telephone lines, cables, wires and conduits. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.05)  
Sec. 70-34. - Operation of cable television system. 
(a)  Signal quality. The permittee's receiving and distribution equipment and facilities shall be constructed, operated and maintained so as to provide usable signals at subscribers' television receivers essentially of the same quality as received at the antenna site. 
(b)  Compliance with laws and regulations. Permittee shall in the operation of its cable television system, comply with all applicable laws, this Code, and rules, regulations and requirements of regulatory agencies. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.06)  
Sec. 70-35. - Services to be provided. 
(a)  Cable television to designated residents. The permittee shall make its cable television service available to all residents of the township who can be reached by its distribution system as mutually agreeable between the township board and the permittee. 
(b)  Public service channels. The permittee shall make available for public use a number of channels as mutually agreeable between the township board and the permittee. 
(c)  Free service to public buildings. The permittee shall furnish free, without monthly fees, installation or service charges, a single television outlet to all schools, fire and police stations in the township: 
(1)  Provided such building is within 400 feet of an existing line of the system; and 
(2)  Provided further that the permittee will not have any responsibility or cost as to any wiring inside the public buildings. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.07)  
Sec. 70-36. - Rate regulation. 
(a)  Basic service and associated equipment. The township adopts by reference rules of the Federal Communications Commission set forth in Subpart N (Cable Rate Regulation) of Part 76 (Cable Television Service) of Chapter I of Title 47 of the Code of Federal Regulations regarding the regulation of cable television rates for basic service and associated equipment, as amended. 
(b)  Public notice of rates and costs. After a cable operator has submitted for review its existing rates for the basic service tier and associated equipment costs or a proposed increase in these rates, the township clerk shall publish a public notice of the rates and costs giving interested parties, including the cable operator, a reasonable opportunity to file written comments which shall be available in the office of the township clerk for public inspection and copying during normal business hours. 
(c)  Confidential business information procedures. The township adopts by reference procedures set forth in 47 CFR 0.459 regarding confidential business information submitted by a cable operator in a rate regulation proceeding. 
(d)  Forfeiture for failure to comply. A cable operator which willfully or repeatedly fails to comply with a rate decision or refund order directed specifically at the cable operator shall be subject to a monetary forfeiture not to exceed $25,000.00 for each violation or each day of a continuing violation not revised to exceed $250,000.00 as determined by the township board following the procedures set forth in 47 USC 503(2)(D), (3)(A) and (B), (4)(A), (B), and (C) which the township adopts by reference. 
(e)  Copy available for inspection or copying. A copy of the rules and procedures adopted by reference in this article are available in the office of the township clerk for public inspection and copying during normal business hours. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.09)  
Secs. 70-3770-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 70-56. - Required. 
No person shall provide cable television service within the limits of the township without first obtaining a permit as provided in this division. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.03.01)  
Sec. 70-57. - Application. 
(a)  Generally. Permits to provide cable television service under this article will be granted by the township board as provided in this article and shall be applied for by written application in a form approved by the township supervisor and filed with the township clerk, which application shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Local business address; 
(3)  Principal officers or owners; 
(4)  Principal stockholders if a corporation; 
(5)  Location of antenna tower or towers; 
(6)  General description of proposed distribution system in the township, showing area proposed to be served and indicating whether applicant will require poles in the streets within the township or whether cables and appliances to be utilized by it in the streets in the township will be located on existing poles of utility companies; and 
(7)  Service to be provided. 
(b)  Financial statement. Each applicant for a permit under this article shall attach to his application an authenticated statement of financial condition and net worth, sufficient in form and content so that the township board may readily determine its financial responsibility and its ability to finance the proposed undertaking. 
(Code 1986, §§ 6-06.03.02, 6-06.03.03)  
Sec. 70-58. - Indemnification. 
(a)  Township held harmless. The permittee shall indemnify and hold the township harmless at all times during the term of this permit and specifically agrees that it will pay all damages and penalties which the township may be legally required to pay as a result of operation of a cable system. 
(b)  Damages and penalties included. Such damages and penalties shall include, but not be limited to, damages arising out of copyright infringements and other damages arising out of the installation, operation, or maintenance of the cable television system authorized in this article, whether or not any act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed, or prohibited by this permit, or this article. 
(c)  Payment of reasonable expenses. The permittee shall pay and by the acceptance of this permit specifically agrees, that it will pay all reasonable expenses incurred by the township in defending itself with regard to all damages, penalties, or other claims resulting from the acts of the permittee, its assigns, employees, agents, invitees, or other persons. 
(d)  Legal fees and services. Expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses such as attorney fees, and shall include the value of any services rendered by the township attorney or any other officers or employees of the township. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.03.04)  
Sec. 70-59. - Insurance. 
(a)  Limits. The permittee shall provide insurance in such form as shall protect the township and itself from and against any and all claims for injury or damage to persons or property, both real and personal, resulting from the construction, erection, operation or maintenance of such television system pursuant to the authority of the permit granted under this article, in limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 for personal injury or death of any one person, $2,000,000.00 for personal injury or death of two or more persons in any one occurrence and $300,000.00 for damage to property resulting from any one occurrence. 
(b)  Workers' compensation. The permittee shall provide workers' compensation insurance as provided by the laws of the state, as amended. 
(c)  Notice of cancellation. All of such insurance coverage shall provide a 30-day notice to the township in the event of material alteration or cancellation of any coverage afforded in such policies prior to the date such material alteration or cancellation shall become effective. 
(d)  Copies filed with clerk. Copies of all certificates of insurance required hereunder shall be furnished to and filed with the township clerk prior to the commencement of operations or the expiration of prior policies as the case may be. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.03.05)  
Sec. 70-60. - Issuance. 
(a)  The township board shall grant a cable television permit under this article to each applicant who makes proper application, establishes its qualifications as set forth in this article, furnishes the required insurance and assurances, and who establishes that its operations will not impose an unreasonable burden on township streets. 
(b)  No permit granted under this article shall be exclusive. 
(c)  An agreement to provide cable television service entered into by the township board and an applicant shall be considered the permit. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.03.06)  
Sec. 70-61. - Renegotiation of terms. 
A permit is granted subject to the right of the township or the permittee to renegotiate the terms of the permit at any time after the effective date of the permit upon 30 days' notice to the permittee if federal or state regulations substantially alter the service, conditions or standards upon which the cable television system is to operate. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.03.07)  
Sec. 70-62. - Fee. 
(a)  A permittee shall pay to the township for the privilege of operating a cable television system under the permit granted pursuant to this article a sum equivalent to five percent of the annual gross subscriber revenue received by the permittee. The permit fee is payable quarterly. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall exempt any permittee from the payment of ad valorem taxes on its property or equipment or on the income earned by it or from any other tax which it might be validly obligated to pay if it were not subject to the permit fee imposed in this article. 
(c)  The permittee shall file with the township clerk, annually, a statement of revenues received from its operations under its permit issued pursuant to this article within 60 days after the close of its fiscal year, and shall make its financial records relating thereto available to the township for inspection at a place designated by it within the township, at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.03.08)  
Sec. 70-63. - Expiration and renewal. 
(a)  Each permit issued under this article shall be for a term of not to exceed 20 years, as agreed to by the township and the permittee or until terminated as provided in this article if termination occurs sooner. The permit granted under this article shall be deemed to constitute a contract between the township and the permittee. 
(b)  Nothing in subsection (a) of this section shall prohibit the permittee from seeking a renewal or extension of a permit. 
(Code 1986, §§ 6-06.03.09, 6-06.03.10)  
Sec. 70-64. - Transfer. 
(a)  Permits granted under this article are not transferable except upon approval of the township board. 
(b)  The proposed transferee shall file an application in a form approved by the township supervisor and shall satisfy all other requirements of this article. 
(c)  Any transfer of the permit by the permittee to one of its subsidiaries shall not be considered transferred with respect to this section. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.03.11)  
Sec. 70-65. - Rights of permittee. 
(a)  Utilizing streets. A permittee shall have the right, so long as its permit is in force and effect, to utilize the streets of the township to the extent set forth in its application, or as otherwise provided by the township board in its permit for the transmission of television and radio and other signals as therein authorized from its antenna location or locations to the premises of subscribers. 
(b)  Erecting cables and appurtenances. 
(1)  By permittee. A permittee may erect all such wires, cables and appurtenances in the streets, subject to approval of the township engineer of the placement of any such poles; or 
(2)  By others. A permittee may, at its option, authorize, subject to the same conditions as to the placement of poles, the installation of such cables and appurtenances by others on a lease, rental, fee or other basis, and all such wires, cables, conduits, appurtenances and poles placed or installed by others for the use of the permittee shall exist and continue to exist solely by authority of the permission granted to the permittee. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.04)  
Sec. 70-66. - Termination. 
(a)  A permittee may surrender its permit at any time, in which event it shall refund to subscribers all prepaid and unearned service and other charges collected from subscribers. 
(b)  In addition to all other rights and powers pertaining to the township by virtue of this article or otherwise, the township preserves the right to terminate and cancel this permit and all rights and privileges of the permittee under this article in the event that the permittee: 
(1)  Violates any provision of the permit or any rule, order or determination of the township, township board or their agents made pursuant to the permit, except where such violation is without fault or through excusable neglect; 
(2)  Becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged as bankrupt; 
(3)  Attempts to evade any of the provisions of this article or practices any fraud or deceit upon the township; or 
(4)  Unless otherwise agreed to: 
a.  Fails to begin the design of the system within 90 days after necessary governmental approvals and pole-leasing agreements from utilities owning such poles; 
b.  Fails to begin construction within six months thereafter; 
c.  Fails to make reasonable efforts to complete construction within 18 months after commencement of such construction; or 
d.  Fails to complete such construction substantially within two years from the effective date of the franchise. 
(c)  A permittee shall be given 60 days' written notice to correct any such default or noncompliance before the township board may proceed to terminate the permit as provided for under this section. 
(d)  A permittee shall be entitled to a hearing before the township board to determine the findings of fact and the propriety of the termination of the permit. 
(e)  The determination of the township board and its decision shall be final. 
(f)  Upon termination of its permit, a permittee shall at its own expense remove from the streets in the township all its facilities and equipment therein utilized by it in its cable television operation, unless the township board shall specifically authorize it to leave all or part of such facilities and equipment in place. 
(Code 1986, § 6-06.03.12)  
Secs. 70-6770-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY BY TELECOMMUNICATIONS PROVIDERS 
 
Sec. 70-101. - Purpose. 
The purposes of this article are to regulate access to and ongoing use of public rights-of-way by telecommunications providers for their telecommunications facilities while protecting the public health, safety, and welfare and exercising reasonable control of the public rights-of-way in compliance with the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002) ("Act") and other applicable law, and to ensure that the city qualifies for distributions under the Act by modifying the fees charged to providers and complying with the Act. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 1, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-102. - Conflict. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed in such a manner as to conflict with the Act or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 2, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-103. - Definitions. 
The terms used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
Act means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002), as amended from time to time. 
Township means the Charter Township of Saginaw. 
Township board means the Township Board of Saginaw Charter Township or its designee. This section does not authorize delegation of any decision or function that is required by law to be made by the township board. 
Township manager means the township manager or his or her designee. 
Permit means a non-exclusive permit issued pursuant to the Act and this article to a telecommunications provider to use the public rights-of-way in the township for its telecommunications facilities. 
All other terms used in this article shall have the same meaning as defined or as provided in the Act, including without limitation the following: 
Authority means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Authority created pursuant to Section 3 of the Act. 
MPSC means the Michigan Public Service Commission in the Department of Consumer and Industry Services, and shall have the same meaning as the term "commission" in the Act. 
Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity, or any other legal entity. 
Public right-of-way in the township means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, alley, easement or waterway. Public right-of-way does not include a federal, state, or private right-of-way. 
Telecommunication facilities or facilities means the equipment or personal property, such as copper and fiber cables, lines, wires, switches, conduits, pipes, and sheaths, which are used to or can generate, receive, transmit, carry, amplify, or provide telecommunication services or signals. Telecommunication facilities or facilities do not include antennas, supporting structures for antennas, equipment shelters or houses, and any ancillary equipment and miscellaneous hardware used to provide federally licensed commercial mobile service as defined in Section 332(d) of part I of title III of the Communications Act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, and service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. 
Telecommunications provider, provider and telecommunications services mean those terms as defined in Section 102 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2102. Telecommunication provider does not include a person or an affiliate of that person when providing a federally licensed commercial mobile radio service as defined in Section 332(d) of part I of the Communications Act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, or service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. For the purpose of the Act and this article only, a provider also includes all of the following: 
(1)  A cable television operator that provides a telecommunications service. 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided by the Act, a person who owns telecommunication facilities located within a public right-of-way. 
(3)  A person providing broadband internet transport access service. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 3, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-104. - Permit required. 
(a)  Permit required. Except as otherwise provided in the Act, a telecommunications provider using or seeking to use public rights-of-way in the township for its telecommunications facilities shall apply for and obtain a permit pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Application. Telecommunications providers shall apply for a permit on an application form approved by the MPSC in accordance with Section 6(1) of the Act. A telecommunications provider shall file one copy of the application with the township clerk, one copy with the township manager, and one copy with the township attorney. Applications shall be complete and include all information required by the Act, including without limitation a route map showing the location of the provider's existing and proposed facilities in accordance with Section 6(5) of the Act. 
(c)  Confidential information. If a telecommunications provider claims that any portion of the route maps submitted by it as part of its application contain trade secret, proprietary, or confidential information, which is exempt from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, pursuant to Section 6(5) of the Act, the telecommunications provider shall prominently so indicate on the face of each map. 
(d)  Application fee. Except as otherwise provided by the Act, the application shall be accompanied by a one-time nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $500.00. 
(e)  Additional information. The township manager may request an applicant to submit such additional information which the township manager deems reasonably necessary or relevant. The applicant shall comply with all such requests in compliance with reasonable deadlines for such additional information established by the township manager. If the township and the applicant cannot agree on the requirement of additional information requested by the township, the township or the applicant shall notify the MPSC as provided in Section 6(2) of the Act. 
(f)  Previously issued permits. Pursuant to Section 5(1) of the Act, authorizations or permits previously issued by the township under Section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251 and authorizations or permits issued by the township to telecommunications providers prior to the 1995 enactment of Section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act but after 1985 shall satisfy the permit requirements of this article. 
(g)  Existing providers. Pursuant to Section 5(3) of the Act, within 180 days from November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, a telecommunications provider with facilities located in a public right-of-way in the township as of such date, that has not previously obtained authorization or a permit under Section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251, shall submit to the city an application for a permit in accordance with the requirements of this article. Pursuant to Section 5(3) of the Act, a telecommunications provider submitting an application under this subsection is not required to pay the $500.00 application fee required under subsection (d) above. A provider under this subsection shall be given up to an additional 180 days to submit the permit application if allowed by the authority, as provided in Section 5(4) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 4, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-105. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  Approval or denial. The authority to approve or deny an application for a permit is hereby delegated to the township manager. Pursuant to Section 15(3) of the Act, the township manager shall approve or deny an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit under subsection 70-104(b) of this article for access to a public right-of-way within the township. Pursuant to Section 6(6) of the Act, the township manager shall notify the MPSC when the township manager has granted or denied a permit, including information regarding the date on which the application was filed and the date on which permit was granted or denied. The township manager shall not unreasonably deny an application for a permit. 
(b)  Form of permit. If an application for permit is approved, the township manager shall issue the permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, in accordance with Sections 6(1), 6(2) and 15 of the Act. 
(c)  Conditions. Pursuant to Section 15(4) of the Act, the township manager may impose conditions on the issuance of a permit, which conditions shall be limited to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Bond requirement. Pursuant to Section 15(3) of the Act, and without limitation on subsection (c) of this section, the township manager may require that a bond be posted by the telecommunications provider as a condition of the permit. If a bond is required, it shall not exceed the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunications provider's access and use. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 5, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-106. - Construction/engineering permit. 
A telecommunications provider shall not commence construction upon, over, across, or under the public rights-of-way in the township without first obtaining a construction or engineering permit for construction within the public rights-of-way. No fee shall be charged for such a construction or engineering permit. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 6, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-107. - Conduit or utility poles. 
Pursuant to Section 4(3) of the Act, obtaining a permit or paying the fees required under the Act or under this article does not give a telecommunications provider a right to use conduit or utility poles. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 7, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-108. - Route maps. 
Pursuant to Section 6(7) of the Act, a telecommunications provider shall, within 90 days after the substantial completion of construction of new telecommunications facilities in the township, submit route maps showing the location of the telecommunications facilities to both the MPSC and to the township. The route maps should be in [paper or electronic] format unless and until the MPSC determines otherwise, in accordance with Section 6(8) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 8, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-109. - Repair of damage. 
Pursuant to Section 15(5) of the Act, a telecommunications provider undertaking an excavation or construction or installing telecommunications facilities within a public right-of-way or temporarily obstructing a public right-of-way in the township, as authorized by a permit, shall promptly repair all damage done to the street surface and all installations under, over, below, or within the public right-of-way and shall promptly restore the public right-of-way to its preexisting condition. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 9, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-110. - Establishment and payment of maintenance fee. 
In addition to the nonrefundable application fee paid to the township set forth in subsection 70-104(d), a telecommunications provider with telecommunications facilities in the township's public rights-of-way shall pay an annual maintenance fee to the authority pursuant to Section 8 of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 10, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-111. - Modification of existing fees. 
In compliance with the requirements of Section 13(1) of the Act, the township hereby modifies, to the extent necessary, any fees charged to telecommunications providers after November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, relating to access and usage of the public rights-of-way, to an amount not exceeding the amounts of fees and charges required under the Act, which shall be paid to the authority. In compliance with the requirements of Section 13(4) of the Act, the township also hereby approves modification of the fees of providers with telecommunication facilities in public rights-of-way within the township's boundaries, so that those providers pay only those fees required under Section 8 of the Act. The township shall provide each telecommunications provider affected by the fee with a copy of this article, in compliance with the requirement of Section 13(4) of the Act. To the extent any fees are charged telecommunications providers in excess of the amounts permitted under the Act, or which are otherwise inconsistent with the Act, such imposition is hereby declared to be contrary to the township's policy and intent, and upon application by a provider or discovery by the township, shall be promptly refunded as having been charged in error. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 11, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-112. - Savings clause. 
Pursuant to Section 13(5) of the Act, if Section 8 of the Act is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, the modification of fees under section 70-111 shall be void from the date the modification was made. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 12, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-113. - Use of funds. 
Pursuant to Section 10(4) of the Act, all amounts received by the township from the authority shall be used by the township solely for rights-of-way related purposes. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 13, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-114. - Annual report. 
Pursuant to Section 10(5) of the Act, the township manager shall file an annual report with the authority on the use and disposition of funds annually distributed by the authority. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 14, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-115. - Cable television operators. 
Pursuant to Section 13(6) of the Act, the township shall not hold a cable television operator in default or seek any remedy for its failure to satisfy an obligation, if any, to pay after November 1, 2002, the effective date of this Act, a franchise fee or similar fee on that portion of gross revenues from charges the cable operator received for cable modem services provided through broadband internet transport access services. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 15, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-116. - Existing rights. 
Pursuant to Section 4(2) of the Act, except as expressly provided herein with respect to fees, this article shall not affect any existing rights that a telecommunications provider or the township may have under a permit issued by the township or under a contract between the township and a telecommunications provider related to the use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 16, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-117. - Compliance. 
The township hereby declares that its policy and intent in adopting this article is to fully comply with the requirements of the Act, and the provisions hereof should be construed in such a manner as to achieve that purpose. The township shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the Act, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Exempting certain route maps from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, as provided in section 70-104(c) of this article; 
(2)  Allowing certain previously issued permits to satisfy the permit requirements hereof, in accordance with section 70-104(f) of this article; 
(3)  Allowing existing providers additional time in which to submit an application for a permit, and excusing such providers from the $500.00 application fee, in accordance with section 70-104(g) of this article; 
(4)  Approving or denying an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit for access to and usage of a public right-of-way within the township, in accordance with section 70-105(a) of this article; 
(5)  Notifying the MPSC when the township has granted or denied a permit, in accordance with section 70-105(a) of this article; 
(6)  Not unreasonably denying an application for a permit, in accordance with section 70-105(a) of this article; 
(7)  Issuing a permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, as provided in section 70-105(b) of this article; 
(8)  Limiting the conditions imposed on the issuance of a permit to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way, in accordance with section 70-105(c) of this article; 
(9)  Not requiring a bond of a telecommunications provider which exceeds the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunication provider's access and use, in accordance with section 70-105(d) of this article; 
(10)  Not charging any telecommunications providers any additional fees for construction or engineering permits, in accordance with section 70-106 of this article; 
(11)  Providing each telecommunications provider affected by the township's right-of-way fees with a copy of this article, in accordance with section 70-111 of this article; 
(12)  Submitting an annual report to the authority, in accordance with section 70-114 of this article; and 
(13)  Not holding a cable television operator in default for a failure to pay certain franchise fees, in accordance with section 70-115 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 17, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-118. - Reservation of police powers. 
Pursuant to Section 15(2) of the Act, this article shall not limit the township's right to review and approve a telecommunication provider's access to and ongoing use of a public right-of-way or limit the township's authority to ensure and protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 18, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-119. - Severability. 
The various parts, sentences, paragraphs, sections, and clauses of this article are hereby declared to be severable. If any part, sentence, paragraph, section, or clause of this article is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, the unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect the constitutionality or validity of any remaining provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 19, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-120. - Authorized township officials. 
The township manager or his or her designee is hereby designated as the authorized township official to issue municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violators to appear in court) or municipal civil infraction violation notices (directing alleged violators to appear at the municipal chapter violations bureau) for violations under this article as provided by the Township Code. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 20, 11-25-2002)  
Sec. 70-121. - Municipal civil infraction. 
A person who violates any provision of this article or the terms or conditions of a permit is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, and shall be subject to Ordinance 601, Section 2-10.02.
