Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the remedies available to the township in the event of a violation by a person of this article or a permit. 
(Ord. No. 634, § 21, 11-25-2002)  
Chapter 74 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Trash, rubbish, junk, or junk vehicles, § 26-34; fires lanes, § 30-121 et seq.; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 38; transportation of persons to illegal places, § 38-6; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; general off-street parking and loading, app. A, § 401 et seq. 
State Law reference Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.1 et seq.; powers of local authorities, MCL 257.606 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 74-1. - Michigan Vehicle Code adopted. 
The Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.) is hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 603, § 2, 11-22-1999; Ord. No. 639, 3-10-2003; Ord. No. 643, 7-14-2003; Ord. No. 648, 9-22-2003; Ord. No. 728, § 1, 5-29-2012) 
State Law reference Authority to adopt statutes by reference, MCL 42.23.  
Sec. 74-2. - Skateboards. 
(a)  In this section, the term "skateboard" means a single platform mounted on wheels, which is propelled solely by human power and which has no mechanism or other device with which to steer or control the movement or direction of the platform. 
(b)  A person who is on a skateboard or who is riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall not ride, operate or in any manner use the vehicle or device on any publicly owned property, including school and township property, except streets and sidewalks within the township. 
(c)  The restrictions contained in this section shall be posted on signs within the areas affected by this section. 
(d)  A police officer apprehending a person for violating this section may impound the skateboard or other device. In the case of a person who is 18 years of age or older, the device shall be released by the police department if the accused appears at the police department and provides identification. To obtain release of a skateboard or other device, persons under the age of 18 years must appear at the police department with a parent or guardian; the skateboard or other device may be released if its owner provides a letter from a parent or guardian requesting that it be released. 
(e)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 610, §§ 15, 4-1-2000)  
Sec. 74-3. - Uniform traffic code. 
The uniform traffic code for cities, townships and villages as promulgated by the director of the Michigan Department of State Police pursuant to the administrative Procedures Act of 1969, 1969 PA 306, MCL 24.201 to 24.328 and made effective October 30, 2002, and all future amendments and revisions to the uniform traffic code when they are promulgated and effective in this state are incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 635, §§ 14, 11-25-2002)  
Secs. 74-474-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BICYCLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Bicycles generally, MCL 257.656; authority to regulate bicycle operation and license and register bicycles, MCL 257.606(1)(i). 
 
Sec. 74-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bicycle means a device powered by human power with two or more wheels in tandem, having handlebars for steering and a saddlelike seat. 
Certificate of title means a document issued at the time of bicycle registration which states the name and address of the owner, the serial number, and the license number of the bicycle. 
Dealer means every person engaged in the business of purchasing, selling, exchanging or dealing in bicycles of a type required to be registered under this article and every person who negotiates the purchase, sale, deal or exchange of such bicycles and who has an established place of business for such purposes in the township. 
License means a decalcomanic print displaying an identification number which is securely affixed to a bicycle in a conspicuous place on the seat pole or the handlebar pole of the bicycle. 
Serial number means the number which a manufacturer stamps into the frame of a bicycle unless the number is not a unique number or there is no manufacturer's serial number, in which case the serial number is a number assigned to a bicycle by the police chief and stamped into the frame of the bicycle. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.02) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 74-32. - Administration. 
The provisions of this article shall be administrated by the police chief. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.03.01) 
Cross reference Administration, ch. 2.  
Sec. 74-33. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  Authority of supervisor to make rules and regulations. The township supervisor is hereby empowered, subject to the approval of the township board, to make reasonable and necessary rules and regulations consistent with the provisions of this article regarding the use, operation and maintenance of any bicycle. No person shall violate any such rule or regulation. 
(b)  Rules effective with published notice. Public notice of all rules and regulations which are made under this article shall become effective when notice of the rules and regulations shall have been given by publication. 
(c)  Authority to temporarily prohibit riding. If the police chief shall determine that conditions believed to be temporary make bicycle riding on any sidewalk or roadway unduly hazardous to either the bicycle riders or to the public, he is authorized to erect signs on any sidewalk or roadway prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon by any person; and when such signs are in place no person shall disobey them. 
(Code 1986, §§ 7-06.03.02, 7-06.03.03)  
Sec. 74-34. - Use of revenues. 
All revenues derived from the registration of bicycles shall be used in financing the provisions of this article and in the promotion of bicycle safety education. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.03.05)  
Sec. 74-35. - Impoundment. 
(a)  Any police officer of the township shall have the power at any time to seize and to take into custody any bicycle found upon the streets, alleys or public places of the township which does not properly display its license and serial number, and anyone found using or operating any such bicycle shall give the police officer his name and address upon request and also a statement as to whether or not such bicycle is registered. 
(b)  Upon such seizure an investigation shall be made to determine whether the bicycle has been properly registered, and if it is found that it is registered, it may be returned to the owner of such bicycle. If the bicycle has not been registered, the owner thereof, upon showing satisfactory proof of ownership, may be permitted to register the bicycle. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall prevent the prosecution of anyone using or operating a bicycle without registration. 
(Code 1986, §§ 7-06.06.017-06.06.03)  
Sec. 74-36. - Parental responsibility. 
No person being the parent or guardian of any child under 17 years of age shall knowingly permit or authorize such child to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.03.04)  
Sec. 74-37. - Registration and license. 
(a)  Required. No resident of the township shall operate a bicycle upon any street, alley or public place of the township unless the bicycle is registered as provided in this section and properly displays a license and serial number. 
(b)  Application; certificate of title. The application for registration under this article shall be on a form furnished by the police chief. The application shall be in duplicate and shall constitute a certificate of title. One copy of the application shall be given to and retained by the applicant, and the other copy shall be placed on file with the police chief. 
(c)  Condition for issuance. Bicycle certificates of title shall be issued by the police chief or by any designated dealer as provided in this article but only after ascertaining that the bicycle desired to be registered is in good mechanical condition. 
(d)  Duration. A bicycle registration shall be permanent so long as it is owned by the licensee. 
(e)  Fee. The fee for bicycle registration shall be as established by resolution. 
(f)  License. The police chief shall also furnish a license, which must be displayed on the registered bicycle at all times and shall not be used on, or transferred to, any bicycle other than that for which it was issued. 
(g)  Tampering prohibited. No person shall willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the serial number, or the license issued under this article. 
(h)  Replacement. Replacement serial number or license shall be issued by the police chief in event the original serial number or license is lost, removed, defaced or destroyed, upon repayment of the initial sum of registration. 
(i)  Issued by selling dealer. All bicycle dealers located within the township shall be required to issue a certificate of title and a license and to record the make and serial number of any bicycle sold by the dealer to a resident of the township. 
(j)  Replaced free. A duplicate certificate of title shall be furnished to the owner at no cost by the police chief in the event that the original certificate of title is lost, defaced, or destroyed. 
(Code 1986, §§ 7-06.04.017-06.04.04, 7-06.04.07)  
Sec. 74-38. - Reports of sales or transfers of ownership. 
(a)  All sales of bicycles to residents of the township by bicycle dealers located within the township shall be reported semimonthly to the police chief. The reports shall be on forms provided by the police chief which shall include, among other things, the make of the bicycle, the serial number of the bicycle, the license number, and the purchaser's name, address and phone number. 
(b)  Any person who sells or transfers ownership of any registered bicycle shall report the sale or transfer by returning to the police chief the certificate of title issued, together with the name and address of the person to whom such bicycle was sold or transferred. Such report shall be made within five days from the date of the sale or transfer. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the purchaser or transferee to apply for transfer of registration within seven days after the sale or transfer. The transfer of registration shall be made upon the condition that the bicycle is in good mechanical condition. The charge for a transfer of title shall be as established by resolution. 
(Code 1986, §§ 7-06.04.05, 7-06.04.06)  
Sec. 74-39. - Obey traffic regulations. 
No person riding a bicycle shall fail to obey the instructions of the traffic regulations of this township applicable to the driver of a vehicle: 
(1)  Except as to special provisions contained in this article; 
(2)  Except as to those provisions of the traffic regulations which by their nature can have no application. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.05.01(A)) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, MCL 257.657.  
Sec. 74-40. - Reasonable speed. 
No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.05.04(C))  
Sec. 74-41. - Obey direction of authorized turn signs. 
Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left or "U" turns are permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the direction or any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.05.01(C))  
Sec. 74-42. - Emerging onto sidewalk or roadway. 
The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building shall stop the bicycle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or into the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching such roadway. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.05.03)  
Sec. 74-43. - Riding on sidewalks. 
(a)  Persons operating bicycles upon a sidewalk shall ride in single file. 
(b)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk when to do so interferes in any way with convenience or safety of pedestrians. 
(c)  No person riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk shall fail to yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian. 
(d)  Persons riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing or before meeting such pedestrian. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.05.02) 
Cross reference Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 
State Law reference Bicycles on sidewalks, MCL 257.660.  
Sec. 74-44. - Parking. 
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at the curb, in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1986, § 7-06.05.05) 

Chapter 78 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 26; floods, ch. 34; public utility maintenance easements, § 34-109; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 62; design standards of adequate water or sewage disposal, § 62-78; required improvements of sanitary sewer lines in subdivisions, § 62-100; telecommunications, ch. 70. 
State Law reference Township water supply and sewage disposal services and facilities, MCL 41.331 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 78-1. - Stormwater drains. 
(a)  Whenever used in this section, except otherwise indicated by the context: 
Readiness-to-serve charge means the amount charged to each premises that received a deferred assessment when it is part of a special assessment district for the improvement of a stormwater drain. 
Stormwater management plan means the current plan regarding stormwater management within the township on file with the director of community development. 
(b)  Any parcel of real estate in the township which is located within the boundaries of a special assessment district created to provide for the improvement of a stormwater drain shall be limited in the amount of stormwater which may be discharged from the premises to the capacity provided, upon which the special assessment was determined. If there is additional stormwater drain capacity available in the special assessment district in which the parcel is located, the property owner may, at the option of the township, purchase from the township additional capacity. Before any improvements are made, a stormwater drain plan shall be approved by the township engineer in accordance with the requirements of the township's stormwater management plan. 
(c)  Where improvements are to be made in the areas of the township which are not located in a special assessment district created to provide for the improvement of a stormwater drain, the owner or developer shall comply with the requirements of the township's stormwater management plan. 
(d)  Prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, it will be necessary that a grading survey, prepared or approved by a registered civil engineer or land survey be submitted to the township building department attesting to the fact that the site is graded in accordance with the drainage pattern approved at the time of issuance of the building or land use permit. 
(e)  If a parcel received a deferred assessment when the assessments were originally spread in a special assessment district for improving a stormwater drain then, at such time as the owner seeks a permit to improve the parcel or at such time as the owner materially alters the imperviousness of the ground, the owner shall pay to the township a readiness-to-serve charge. If a parcel which received a deferred assessment is split into parcels less than ten acres in size, in that event, the property owner shall at that time pay the readiness-to-serve charge provided in this section. The readiness-to-serve charge shall be determined by the amount of the deferred assessment as shown on the assessment roll of the special assessment district in which the property is located plus interest of payment at the same rate as provided for in the special assessment district for unpaid assessments. 
(f)  No permit shall be issued by the township until readiness-to-serve charge is paid. No site plan shall be approved or building or any other permit issued unless the owner has complied with all requirements of the township's stormwater management plan, as determined by the township engineer. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 6-04.08, 6-15-1998)  
Secs. 78-278-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 78-31. - Definition. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
System means the township water supply and distribution system. 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 78-32. - Supervision and control. 
The operation, maintenance and management of the system shall be under the immediate supervision and control of the township board or of such officer or board as shall be designated or created by the township board and subject to its control. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.06.01)  
Sec. 78-33. - Fiscal year. 
The system shall be operated upon the basis of a fiscal year beginning on April 1 of each year and ending on March 31 of the following year. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.12)  
Sec. 78-34. - Connections and extensions. 
(a)  Connections by authorized representative. Water connections to the system water mains shall be installed only by the authorized representative of the township board. 
(b)  Inspection prior to covering. No water main, water connection or water extension shall be covered until inspected and approved by the authorized representative of the township board, who shall be notified when such construction is ready for inspection. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.06.02(A), (B))  
Sec. 78-35. - Water service turn on or shut off. 
No person, other than the authorized representative of the township board, shall turn on or shut off water service, except that a licensed plumber may turn on a water service for testing his work (then it must be immediately turned off). 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.06.02(C))  
Sec. 78-36. - Cross connections prohibited. 
No person shall make or permit to be made any cross connection whatsoever between the water system, or any extension thereof or connection therewith, and any other water system or supply of water, whether such other system or supply be public or private and whether any such cross connection be in or upon public or private property. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.06.02(D))  
Sec. 78-37. - Water meters. 
(a)  Requirement established. Except as otherwise provided in this article, water to be furnished by the system to each premises shall be measured by a meter installed and controlled by the township. 
(b)  Outdoor registers. All individual meters shall be equipped with an outdoor register, such register to be installed by the township and charges therefor will be paid for and borne by the water users and customers. 
(c)  Tampering prohibited. No person other than an authorized employee or representative of the township shall break or injure the seal on or change the location of, alter or interfere in any way with any meter that is the property of or has been furnished by the township. 
(d)  Faulty metering. If a meter shall fail to register properly, the township supervisor is empowered to estimate the quantity of water used on the basis of former consumption and bill accordingly. 
(e)  Inspection and reading. No person shall refuse to admit to premises owned or occupied by him or hinder any authorized agent of the township entering such premises for the purpose of reading a water meter or inspecting a water meter or any piping in connection with the water distribution system. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.06.03)  
Sec. 78-38. - Water hydrants. 
(a)  Unauthorized use. No person other than an authorized employee of the township shall break, injure, or turn on or turn off, or use or interfere in any way with any water hydrant. 
(b)  Obstructions prohibited. No person shall place any building material or any other obstruction, nor shall any person responsible for such material or obstruction, nor any person owning property immediately adjoining a fire hydrant, shall permit such material or obstruction within 15 feet of any fire hydrant or fire plug. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.06.04) 
Cross reference Fire prevention and protection, ch. 30.  
Sec. 78-39. - Installation, maintenance and repair costs. 
(a)  Meters, connections and extensions. Each water customer of the system shall pay the costs of such water meter or meters, water connections, water extensions, including the installation, maintenance and repair thereof. 
(b)  Water main connections. 
(1)  Service fee. The owner of each premises in the township abutting a street or easement in which a water main is located, at such time as a connection is made, shall pay a service fee to the township in an amount determined by multiplying the frontage of the parcel times the rate per foot as established by resolution of the township board, except those parcels in platted subdivisions where water mains were paid for by the developer and except those parcels which have been assessed for a water main improvement; provided any structure farther than 200 feet from the front property line being serviced by the connection shall pay an additional service fee in such amount as determined by the township manager to be reasonable under the circumstances there existing. Such costs shall be no more than the estimated costs to be incurred by the township in making the connection. 
(2)  Hookup fees. The owners of all premises connecting to a water main shall pay a service fee and also a connection fee to the township in amounts to be determined from time to time by resolution of the township board for a water main. 
(3)  Payment. The service and connection fees set forth in this section for each lot or parcel must be paid prior to issuance of any building permits and prior to providing the water connection to a premises that is not currently served. 
(4)  Water main extensions not required. The township shall not be required or obligated to extend any water mains within the township. 
(c)  Damaged meters or hydrants. Whenever a water meter or a water hydrant is injured because of any act or negligence on the part of the owner or occupant of the premises where such meter is installed or hydrant is located, the expense to the township caused thereby shall be charged to and collected from such owner or occupant. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.07)  
Sec. 78-40. - Water main deferred assessments; readiness-to-serve charge. 
(a)  The township board may defer a portion of the sum to be assessed as provided in section 9a of Public Act No. 188 of 1954 (MCL 41.729a) if a parcel to be assessed is ten acres or more or if a parcel owner can demonstrate additional facts showing the proposed assessments would constitute a hardship. 
(b)  Such deferred assessment shall be a lien upon the property receiving the assessment upon recording of a notice of deferred assessment. Such notice of deferred assessment shall be recorded prior to the date the assessments can be paid without interest. 
(c)  If a parcel received a deferred assessment when the assessments were originally spread in a special assessment district created for improving water mains then, at such time as the owner seeks a permit to improve the parcel, the owner shall pay the township a readiness-to-serve charge. If a parcel which received a deferred assessment is split into parcels less than ten acres in size, in that event the property owner shall at that time pay the readiness-to-serve charge provided in this section. The readiness-to-serve charge shall be determined by the amount of the deferred assessment as shown on the assessment roll of the special assessment district in which the property is located plus interest until paid at the same rate as provided for in the special assessment district for unpaid assessments; provided, interest shall not accrue on unpaid assessments for more than 15 years. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall be enforceable through the bringing of appropriate action for injunction, mandamus, or otherwise, in any court having jurisdiction. 
(e)  To improve parcel or alter ground. Parcels, which received a deferred assessment when the assessments were originally spread in special assessment districts for the Hospital Road water main on October 22, 1979, and where the owner of a parcel consents in writing, shall pay to the township a readiness-to-serve charge on or before November 1, 2003. 
(f)  The readiness-to-serve charge for those parcels set forth in subsection (e) shall be determined by the amount of the deferred assessment as shown on the assessment roll of the special assessment district in which the property is located. However, the assessment shall not include interest at the same rate as provided for in the special assessment district for unpaid assessments after November 1, 2003. Thereafter, the readiness to serve charge, excluding any interest, may be paid in full at any time prior to November 1, 2003. Any readiness-to-serve charge not paid, will be divided by November 1, 2003 into ten equal annual installments beginning December 1, 2003 and the same amount on the same day of the same month each year thereafter until fully paid. Said installments shall bear interest from November 1, 2003 at the rate of six percent per annum. Such readiness-to-serve charge, or any installments, not paid when due shall be considered delinquent and shall constitute a lien upon the respective parcel and shall be collected in the same manner as delinquent taxes. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.08; Ord. No. 647, 9-8-2003)  
Secs. 78-4178-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - USER RATES AND CHARGES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Rates, MCL 141.121. 
 
Sec. 78-56. - Meter charges per quarter. 
Except as otherwise provided in this division, water to be furnished by the system to each premises shall be measured by a meter installed and controlled by the township. Charges for water service to each premises within the water system connected with the water supply system, for each quarterly (three-month) period, shall be as established by resolution. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.01)  
Sec. 78-57. - Consumption charge per quarter. 
In addition to the quarterly meter charge for use of water, there shall be a quarterly consumption charge in accordance with the schedule established by resolution. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.02; Ord. No. 566, § 6-02.09.02, 1-27-1997)  
Sec. 78-58. - Electrical power cost for pumping. 
There shall be an additional charge in cents per 1,000 gallons, based upon the township's costs for the purchase of electrical power for pumping purposes as determined by the most recent Consumers Power Company billing. This charge will be computed by multiplying the township's cost for electrical power, in cents per kilowatt-hour, times 4.354. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.03)  
Sec. 78-59. - Minimum quarterly charge. 
The minimum quarterly water charge shall be the meter charge. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.04)  
Sec. 78-60. - Private fire line connection charges. 
The minimum charge for private fire line connections shall be as established by resolution. The township board reserves the right to meter any private fire line. The charge for metered fire lines shall be the quarterly meter charge plus the quarterly connection charge or the quarterly meter charge plus the quarterly consumption charge, whichever is the largest. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.05)  
Sec. 78-61. - Premises outside water system. 
Charges for water service to premises outside the water district shall be fixed by the township board but shall be not less than those for services within the district. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.06)  
Sec. 78-62. - Rate revisions authorized. 
The rates established are estimated to be sufficient to provide for the payment of the expenses of administration and operation of the system and such expenses for the maintenance thereof as may be necessary to preserve the system in good repair and working order; to provide for the payment of the interest upon and the principal of all bonds payable therefrom, as and when the bonds shall become due and payable, and for the creation of reserves for the payment of principal and interest as required in this article; and to provide for such other expenditures and funds for the system as are required by this article. Rates shall be fixed and revised from time to time by the township board so as to produce the foregoing amounts, and the township covenants and agrees to maintain at all times such rates for services furnished by the system as shall be sufficient to provide for the foregoing. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.11)  
Sec. 78-63. - Billing frequency. 
Charges for services furnished by the water system shall be billed and collected quarterly or as often as shall be determined by the township board. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.07(A))  
Sec. 78-64. - Due date. 
Water charges shall become due at such time not exceeding 20 days from date of billing which shall be within a reasonable time after the reading of the meter. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.07(B))  
Sec. 78-65. - Nonpayment penalty. 
If water charges are not paid on or before such due date, then a penalty of five percent shall be added thereto for any late payment in excess of one occurring within two years. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.07(C))  
Sec. 78-66. - Discontinuance of service. 
If the charges for any such services furnished to any premises shall not be paid within 30 days after the due date thereof, then all services furnished by the system to such premises shall be discontinued. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.07(D))  
Sec. 78-67. - Shutoff and turn-on charges. 
Water services discontinued for nonpayment of bills shall not be restored until all sums then due and owing, including penalties, shall be paid, plus a shutoff charge and a turnon charge in the amount established by resolution. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.07(E); Ord. No. 566, § 6-02.09.07, 1-27-1997)  
Sec. 78-68. - Other collection remedies. 
(a)  Lien on property. Charges for services furnished by the system to any premises shall be a lien thereon. 
(b)  Charges added to tax roll. On September 1 of each year, the person or agency charged with the management of the system shall certify any such charges which have been delinquent six months or more to the supervisor who shall enter the charges upon the next tax roll against the premises to which such services shall have been rendered, and such charges shall be collected and the lien shall be enforced in the same manner as provided in respect to taxes assessed upon such roll. 
(c)  Tenants excluded. 
(1)  Filing of notice with lease. Provided, that when a tenant is responsible for payment of any such charge against such premises, and the township board is so notified in writing, with a copy of the lease of the affected premises (if there is one) attached, then no such charge shall become a lien against such premises from and after the date of such notice. 
(2)  Security cash deposit. However, in the event of the filing of such notice, no further service shall be rendered by the system to such premises until a cash deposit equal to three times the average quarterly (three-month) charge to such premises shall have been made as security for the payment of charges thereto. 
(Code 1986, § 6-02.09.08) 
State Law reference Lien for charges, MCL 141.121(3), 123.161 et seq.  
Secs. 78-6978-85. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - WATER EMERGENCIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference Lien for charges, MCL 141.121(3), 123.161 et seq. 
 
Sec. 78-86. - Determination of water emergency. 
When the township board and/or the township supervisor shall determine that the consumption of water by the township has or is about to equal or exceed the total supply available to the township, they shall declare that a critical water consumption period exists and place in effect the restrictions set forth of this division. 
(Code 1986, § 8-03.02)  
Sec. 78-87. - Declaration of water emergency. 
At such time as the township board and/or the township supervisor shall determine that water consumption within the township has or is about to equal or exceed the supply available to the township, they shall declare that a water emergency exists. 
(Code 1986, § 8-03.03)  
Sec. 78-88. - Notice of water emergency. 
When the township board and/or the township supervisor shall have declared that a water emergency exists as provided in section 78-87, notice thereof shall be given by releasing the notice to a newspaper of general circulation in the township and to all radio and television stations maintaining offices or studios within the township or within the City of Saginaw. Such notice shall advise of the time of commencement of such emergency and that the emergency will continue until notice of termination thereof is given by the township board through the same media. 
(Code 1986, § 8-03.04)  
Sec. 78-89. - Uses prohibited. 
When the township board and/or the township supervisor shall have declared that a water emergency exists as provided in section 78-87, the use and withdrawal of water by any person from the township water distribution system for any of the following purposes is hereby prohibited: 
(1)  Watering of yards. The sprinkling, watering or irrigation of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens, vegetables, flowers, or any other vegetation. 
(2)  Cleaning outdoor surfaces. The washing of sidewalks, driveways, filling station aprons, porches and other services. 
(3)  Swimming pools. Swimming and wading pools not employing a filter and recirculating system. 
(4)  Escape through defective plumbing. The escape of water through defective plumbing, which shall mean the knowing permission for defective plumbing to remain out of repair. 
(Code 1986, § 8-03.05)  
Sec. 78-90. - Termination of water emergency. 
When the township board and/or the township supervisor shall determine that the conditions which caused the declaration of the emergency under section 78-87 no longer exists, they shall so declare and give notice of such determination as provided in section 78-88. 
(Code 1986, § 8-03.06)  
Sec. 78-91. - Violations. 
Any person who shall knowingly, during any such water emergency, use or withdraw water from the township water-distribution system for any of the purposes prohibited in section 78-89, shall be responsible for a civil infraction and shall in addition, if he refuses to discontinue such violation, be subject to the discontinuance of water service during the continuance of such emergency. 
(Code 1986, § 8-03.07)  
Secs. 78-9278-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 78-121. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building sewer means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the sewer connection, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
Connection means the sewer connection from the public sewer in the street or easement to the property line. 
Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage, and sale of produce. 
Industrial wastes means the liquid and/or solid waste from industrial processes as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, river, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
Person means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation, or group. 
Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
Readiness-to-serve charge means the amount charged to each premises that received a deferred assessment when it is part of a special assessment district for the improvement of a storm drain. 
Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwater, surface water, and groundwater are not intentionally admitted. 
Service fee means the amounts as determined by subsections 78-126(a) and (b). 
Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters as may be present. 
Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
Sewage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage. 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
Storm sewer and storm drain mean a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
Superintendent means the superintendent of the sewage works or in each instance the authorized deputy, agent, or representative. 
Unit means that quantity of sanitary sewage ordinarily arising from a residential building occupied by a single family. 
Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.02) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 78-122. - Superintendent. 
(a)  The township board shall appoint a sewage works superintendent who shall under the direction of the township board have charge of the operation and maintenance of the sewage works of the township and shall direct and control all other employees of the sewage works system. 
(b)  The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the township bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purposes of meter reading, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The compensation of such employees including the superintendent, shall be fixed, determined, and may be changed from time to time by the township board. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.04)  
Sec. 78-123. - Violation of article. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this article except section 78-1, subsection 78-124(e), subsections 78-126(a) through (e) and section 78-125, shall be served by the township with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notices, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article covered by subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall become liable to the township for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned the township by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.11)  
Sec. 78-124. - Unlawful disposal; prohibited discharges; connection to sewer required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the township, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the township, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet or watercourse within the township, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the township, any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(c)  The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the township and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located, or may in the future be located, a public sanitary sewer of the township, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within six months after date of official notice to do so. 
(d)  At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property not now served by a public sanitary sewer, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, and any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, and similar private sewage disposal facilities thereon located shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(e)  The connection to the sewer shall be completed within six months after the date of the occurrence of the last of the following events: 
(1)  Availability of the public sanitary sewage collection facility; 
(2)  Improvement of the property so as to become property from which sanitary sewage emanates; 
(3)  April 1, 1987. 
(f)  In the event of failure to connect to the public sanitary sewage collection facility as above provided, and if such failure to connect shall continue for an additional 90 days after notice has been sent by the township by first class mail or posted on the property stating that the structure shall be connected and giving the approximate location of the public sanitary sewer system which is available for connection of the structure involved and of the requirements and the enforcement provisions of this section and section 78-126, the township may bring an action for a mandatory injunction or order in the district or circuit court in the county to compel the owner to connect to the available sanitary sewer system forthwith. 
(Code 1986, §§ 6-04.03, 6-04.10)  
Sec. 78-125. - Destruction of sewage works facilities prohibited. 
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the township's sewage works. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.09.01)  
Sec. 78-126. - Service and connection fees. 
(a)  Residential service fees. Each residence in the township abutting or within 300 feet of a street or easement in which a sanitary sewer or combined sewer is installed shall be connected to such sewer and at the time of connection shall pay a service fee to the township in an amount determined by applying the number of units as derived from subsection (f) of this section to the amount of the unit assessment as determined from time to time by resolution of the township board. 
(b)  Nonresidential service fee. Each business, or commercial structure other than a single-family residence, from which sanitary sewage is generated and which abuts a street or easement in which a sanitary sewer or combined sewer is installed, shall connect to such sewer. At the time of original connection, or expansions, or change of existing use, a service fee shall be paid to the township in an amount determined by applying the number of units, as derived from subsection (f) of this section to the amount of the unit assessment. In cases of changes of existing use, the calculated service fee shall be reduced by the amount of service fee paid on previous uses after April 1, 1987. In cases of expansion of a use existing prior to April 1, 1987, the service fee shall be based on the expansion only. Where two or more categories of business are served by one connection, the total service fee shall be the sum of the individual service fees calculated for all such categories. 
(c)  Connection fee. All premises connecting to a sanitary sewer or combined sewer shall pay a service fee to the township in amounts to be determined from time to time by resolution of the township board. 
(d)  Credits cancelled. All existing credits, except those provided for by legal and binding agreements entered into by the township board, are hereby cancelled as of April 1, 1987, unless a building permit is applied for before April 1, 1987, and construction begins prior to July 1, 1987. 
(e)  Cash prepayments. All parcels having paid previous service and connection fees prior to April 1, 1987, shall be charged for the service fees under the provisions of this article, less the amount of cash prepayments. 
(f)  Unit schedule. 
(1)  Schedule for determining number of units. 
Land Use 	Unit Dwelling 
Residential 	1.00 per dwelling unit 
Commercial 	0.25 per 1,000 square feet gross building area 
Eating and drinking establishments 	2.25 per 1,000 square feet gross building area 
Car wash (automatic) 	18.50 per wash line 
Car wash (self-serve) 	4.50 per stall 
Motel 	0.27 per unit 
Warehouses 	0.10 per 1,000 square feet gross building area 
Industrial (exclusive of industrial waste) 	0.50 per 1,000 square feet gross building area 
Laundromat 	0.50 per washer 
Retirement village (including eating and laundry facilities) 	1.00 per dwelling unit 
 
(2)  Special additional charge. In addition to the above unit schedule, there shall be added a charge of $4,625.00. Pursuant to Ordinance No. 430 interest on this amount accrues at eight percent per annum. A record owner of any parcel of land on Fashion Square Boulevard between McCarty Road and Vogue Commercial Park connecting to the sewer system after September 1, 2004 and prior to September 1, 2006 and, who applies in writing, shall have all accrued interest on the connection fee capped as of August 31, 1996. For parcels connecting on or after September 1, 2006 interest at six percent per annum shall be charged from that date on the capped amount. 
(3)  Minimum charge; special situations. The minimum charge shall be one unit. Special situations or categories not specifically covered in this unit schedule shall be determined by the township manager in consultation with the director of community development, director of public services, and the township engineer. 
(Code 1986, §§ 6-04.05, 6-04.0A; Ord. No. 671, 9-13-2004)  
Secs. 78-12778-145. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 78-146. - Connection permit. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent. No charge will be made for this permit. 
(b)  Applications for service connections to the sanitary sewer system of the township shall be made in writing on forms furnished by the township. 
(c)  The required service fee for each lot or parcel must be paid prior to the issuance of any building or sewer connection permits. 
(d)  The superintendent shall be notified at least 24 hours in advance of the installation of a sewer connection from the public sewer to the property line so that such connection may be properly inspected and approved. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.01)  
Sec. 78-147. - Installation responsibility. 
If a connection does not exist, it is the responsibility of the property owner to construct or to provide for the construction of such connection according to the requirements and specifications of the township. That portion of the sewer connection from the property line to the building sewer shall be installed by the applicant at his own expense, and this portion of the sewer connection shall not be backfilled until inspected and approved by the superintendent. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.02)  
Sec. 78-148. - Connection specifications. 
A separate and independent sewer connection shall be provided for every building. Except where one building stands at the rear of another or on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the sewer connection from the front building may be extended to the rear building. Old sewer connections may be used in connection with existing or new buildings only when they are found, upon examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.03)  
Sec. 78-149. - Excavations. 
All excavations required for the installation of sewer connections shall be in open cut unless otherwise approved by the superintendent. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.04)  
Sec. 78-150. - Connection into public sanitary sewer. 
(a)  Existing opening. The connection of the building sewer into the public sanitary sewers shall be made at a Wye or Tee opening provided for that purpose if such opening is available at a suitable location. 
(b)  New opening. Connections to the sanitary sewer at places other than at a Wye or Tee opening, shall be made under the direct supervision of the superintendent in a manner to provide a water tight joint with no obstructions in the public sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.05)  
Sec. 78-151. - Building sewers. 
(a)  Materials. The sewer connections from the sanitary sewer in the street or easement to within five feet of the inside wall of any house or building shall consist of vitrified clay sewer pipe conforming to ASTM Specifications for Clay Sewer Pipe Designation C-13 or PVC pipe as approved by the Michigan Plumbing Code, Class 2400 and the latest revisions thereof. 
(b)  Size and slope. The size and slope of the sewer connection shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent, but in no event shall the diameter from the public sewer to the property line be less than six inches. From the property line to the sewer outlet at the building the size may be reduced to four inches, otherwise the size shall be six inches. The slope of such six-inch pipe shall be not less than one-eighth inch per foot, unless otherwise permitted. 
(c)  Depth and location. Whenever possible the sewer connection shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No sewer connection shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The depth to invert shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost and not less than five feet below the grade line at the house. The sewer connection shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings. 
(d)  Low drains. In all buildings in which any building sewer is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the sewer connection. 
(e)  Shared trench with water service. Sewer connections may be laid in the same trench with a water service only when the water service is at least one foot above and 1½ feet horizontally from the sewer connection and both places on undisturbed earth. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.06)  
Sec. 78-152. - Joints. 
Joints shall be tight and waterproof. Joints on vitrified clay sewer pipe shall conform to standard specifications of ASTM Designation: C-425-58T, Type I or Type III or the latest revisions thereof. Joints on PVC pipe shall be as specified by the pipe manufacturer. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.07)  
Sec. 78-153. - Pipe laying and backfilling. 
Pipe shall be laid and backfilled in accordance with the best construction practice providing uniform bearing throughout the entire length of the pipe. No backfill shall be placed until the pipe in place has been inspected and approved by the superintendent. The backfill shall be placed by hand shovels and thoroughly tamped under on both sides of the pipe to the level of the top of the pipe. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.08)  
Secs. 78-15478-170. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - GENERAL DISCHARGE RESTRICTIONS 
 
Sec. 78-171. - Unpolluted drainage. 
(a)  Roof water. 
(1)  In all cases where the building is equipped with eaves troughs or other means for the collection of roof water, the downspouts and/or roof water conductor pipes shall be discharged on the ground or paved surface at a distance of at least 36 inches from the building wall, unless otherwise approved by the building official. 
(2)  The grade line at the building wall in all cases shall be such that the slope is away from the wall at the rate of at least one-quarter inch per foot. In cases where settlement of the ground has occurred at the building wall, it shall be the responsibility of the property owner to add fill to correct the condition to conform with the slope requirement of this subsection. 
(b)  Window well drainage. There shall be no direct connection from the window wells to the foundation drain. 
(c)  Basement perimeter tile drainage. Basement perimeter tile, or footing drains shall not be connected to sanitary sewers unless the township manager or his designee determines that it is not feasible to discharge such stormwater or clear water into an open ditch and if an enclosed storm drainage system is not available. 
(d)  Applicability of drainage requirements. The requirements of this section shall apply to all sanitary sewers, combined sewers and storm sewers in the township. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.07.01)  
Sec. 78-172. - Clear water or stormwater drain connections. 
(a)  Surface drains, groundwater drains, and foundation footing drains shall be connected whenever possible to an enclosed storm sewer and shall not be connected to a building sewer which discharges into a sanitary sewer or private wastewater treatment plant, except that clear water or stormwater drains that have been connected to sanitary sewers and approved by the township prior to July 4, 1980, may continue to be connected without penalty, until such time as an enclosed stormwater sewer is installed. All clear water or stormwater hookups not specifically prohibited in other Code provisions are and will be permitted in the Weiss and Center Road Drainage Districts. 
(b)  Footing drains that have been terminating at and emptying onto the surface or into drainage ditches shall be connected to an enclosed stormwater drainage system or connections thereto whenever such systems or connections are available. 
(c)  If unapproved stormwater or clear water is being discharged into a sanitary sewer, the township shall give the offending property owner 30 days notice to disconnect. Failure to disconnect after such notice shall authorize the township to cause disconnection and assessment of the costs of such disconnection against the property involved. The township may, in the alternative, institute action for violation of this section. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.06.02)  
Sec. 78-173. - Cooling or unpolluted process water. 
Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may and/or shall be discharged to a storm sewer or natural outlet, as directed by the superintendent. 
(Code 1986, § 6-04.07.03)  
Secs. 78-17478-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - INDUSTRIAL DISCHARGES 
 
Sec. 78-191. - Definitions. 
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this division and related regulations shall be as follows: 
Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, PL 92-500 (33 USC 1251 et seq.), which is on file in the office of the director. 
Authorized representative of industrial user means: 
(1)  In the case of a corporation, a president, secretary, treasurer or vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function or any other person who performs similar policy-making or decision-making functions for the corporation, or the principal manager of one or more manufacturing, production or operation facilities employing more than 250 persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures of more than $25,000,000.00, in second-quarter 1980 dollars, if the authority to sign the documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures; 
(2)  In the case of a partnership or proprietorship, a general partner or proprietor; 
(3)  In the case of a limited liability company, a member; and 
(4)  An authorized representative of the individual designated above if: 
a.  Such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the discharge into the POTW originates; 
b.  The authorization is in writing; and 
c.  The written authorization is submitted to the POTW. 
Baseline monitoring report means the initial report provided by the user when making out an application for an industrial waste sewer user permit, signed by the person in charge of the entire facility or an assigned subordinate of such person, and which shall comply with the requirements of 40 CFR 403.12(b)(1)(7) as a minimum. 
Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius expressed in milligrams per liter. 
Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge of soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the sewer extension beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
Bypass means the intentional diversion of wastewater from any portion of a user's treatment facility, needed for noncompliance with pretreatment standards. 
Categorical standards and categorical pretreatment standards mean and refer to National Categorical Pretreatment Standards or a pretreatment standard as promulgated under 40 CFR 403 under authority of the act, which apply to a specific category of users. 
Chemical oxygen demand (COD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the chemical oxidation of organic matter with a strong chemical oxidant under standard laboratory procedure and expressed in milligrams per liter. 
Commencement of construction means the owner or operator has begun, or caused to begin: 
(1)  Any placement, assembly or installation of facilities or equipment; 
(2)  Significant site preparation work, including clearing, excavation or removal of existing buildings, structures or facilities, which is necessary for the placement of new construction; or 
(3)  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment, which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. 
Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this definition. 
Compatible pollutants means those pollutants that the wastewater treatment plant has been designed for specific removal of and BOD, TSS, fecal coliform bacteria, total phosphorous and any other constituent that may be determined effectively treatable and added as such to the NPDES permit in the future. 
Compliance monitoring report means the discharge report submitted in June and December of each year, or other times as deemed necessary or appropriate by the director, as noted in section 78-194(k)(5). 
Corporate officer means the person being a president, vice-president, secretary or treasurer of the corporation, or a person given significant policies or decision-making power for the corporation, or a general partner of a partnership, or any proprietor or owner. 
Director means the director of public services for the township, or the authorized deputy, agent or representative of such person. 
Discharger, industrial discharger means any nonresidential user who discharges an effluent, other than sanitary sewage, into a POTW by means of pipes, conduits, pumping stations, force mains, constructed drainage ditches, surface water intercepting ditches, intercepting ditches and all constructed devices and appliances appurtenant thereto. 
Dissolved solids means the solids in wastewater, other than suspended solids. 
Domestic sewer user means a person in any residence in the township or any service area provided sewage treatment services by the township. 
Domestic wastes means normal wastes from residential living units resulting from day-to-day activities, such as, but not limited to, dishwater, laundry water, bath water, sink water, shower water, toilet water and ground garbage, but shall not include incompatible pollutants. 
Excessive discharge means a discharge of wastes in such magnitude that, in the judgment of the director, it will cause damage to any facility, will be harmful to the sewage treatment process, cannot be removed in the sewage treatment plant to the degree required to meet the act, can otherwise endanger life, limb or public property, and/or can constitute a public nuisance. 
Existing site construction means a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure or facility, or meet the definition of the term "new construction," but does alter, replace or add to an existing process or production equipment. 
Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking or serving of food, from the handling, storage and sale of produce or from the canning or packaging of food. Garbage is composed largely of putrescible organic matter and its natural or added moisture content. 
Incompatible pollutant means any pollutant which is not defined in this section as a compatible pollutant. 
Industrial sewer user permit means a sewer user permit required of any nondomestic sewer user determined to need a permit. 
Industrial wastes means the liquid, solid or gaseous wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, food processing, laboratories, trades or businesses, as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
Industry means an establishment with facilities for industrial manufacturing processes, food processing, laboratories, trades or businesses. 
Manager means the township manager, or the authorized deputy, agent or representative of such person. 
May is permissive. See Shall. 
Milligrams per liter (mg/l) means measured concentrations of substances present, and is considered equal to parts per million. 
National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit (NPDES permit) means the permit issued to the township by the state department of environmental quality. 
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, river, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or subsurface water. 
New construction means: 
(1)  A building, structure, facility or installation that is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; 
(2)  A building, structure, facility or installation that totally replaces process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
(3)  The wastewater generating processes of a building, structure, facility or installation that are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. 
New source means: 
(1)  Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of the proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the Clean Water Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; 
b.  The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
c.  The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. 
In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source should be considered. 
(2)  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of subsection (1)b. or (1)c. of this definition, but otherwise alters, replaces or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
(3)  Construction of a new source as defined under this definition has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun, or caused to begin, as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
1.  Any placement, assembly or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
2.  Significant site preparation work, including clearing, excavation or removal of existing buildings, structures or facilities, which is necessary for the placement, assembly or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this definition. 
Nondomestic sewer user means any nonresidential sewer user. 
Operational upset means any disruption to the treatment plant process caused by any materials alone or in combination with other materials. 
Pass through means a discharge from the treatment plant into waters of the state in quantities or concentrations that cause the plant to violate this division or its NPDES permit. 
Person means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation, group, trust, governmental authority or other legal entity. 
pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions in moles per liter of solution. 
Pollutant means any substance discharged into a POTW or its collection system, listed in section 78-206. 
POTW means publicly owned treatment works and shall include the entire gravity collection system, pump stations and force mains in addition to an actual sewage treatment plant. 
Properly shredded garbage means garbage that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, if any, and which is controlled by public authority. 
Receiving waters means any watercourse, river, pond, ditch, lake, aquifer or other body of surface or subsurface water receiving discharge of sewage. 
Sanitary sewage means domestic wastes from residences and domestic-type wastes from business buildings, institutions, industrial establishments and all other sources, and shall also include groundwater seepage into the sanitary sewer pipe. 
Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and subsurface waters are not intentionally admitted. 
Severe property damage means substantial physical damage to property, damage to the treatment facilities which causes the facilities to become inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources which can reasonably be expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. Such term does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production. 
Sewage means a combination of water and water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, industrial establishments and any other sources, together with such subsurface water, surface water and stormwater as may be present. 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying stormwaters and/or wastewaters. 
Sewer connection means the part of the sewerage system connected to and extending from the sewer main to the lot line of abutting property or extended to that distance from the sewer main as considered necessary by the director. 
Sewer extension means the part of the sewerage system extending from the sewer connection onto the premises served. 
Sewer main means the part of the sewerage system intended to serve one or more sewer connections, catchbasins, inlets or other permitted connections or conduits. 
Sewerage system means all properties, structures, manholes, catchbasins, inlets, pipes, equipment and conduits for the purpose of collecting, treating, testing and dispensing of domestic wastewater and/or industrial waters or other wastewaters, as existing, added to, expanded or improved. 
Shall is mandatory. See May. 
Shall discharge means discharging, causing or allowing to be discharged, either directly or indirectly. 
Significant industrial user means any industrial user subject to categorical standards or a noncategorical discharger to the sewerage system who has a discharge flow of 25,000 gallons or more per day; or contributes five percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW; or has any toxic materials in the EPA priority pollutant list; or has any materials on the site listed in the MDEQ critical materials register; or has on the site any materials in the MDEQ land application unit test list for land application of sludge; or is designated as such by the township on a basis that it has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement; or has any material on the site that is found by the township, MDEQ or EPA to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with wastes from other contributing users on the wastewater treatment system, the quality of the sludge, the treatment plant effluent quality, the receiving water quality or air emissions generated by the sewerage system. 
Sludge contamination means any material deposited in the sludge that will, by itself or with other materials, render the sludge unusable for land application or landfilling and/or violate the NPDES permit. 
Slug loading means any discharge of a nonroutine, episodic nature, including, but not limited to, an accidental spill or a noncustomary batch discharge. 
Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) means a classification based on the most current publication of the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, Office of Management and Budget of the United States of America. 
Standard Methods means the latest edition of the "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association, the American Waterworks Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation, which is available for review at the POTW. 
State means the State of Michigan, its departments and offices. 
Storm sewer and storm drain mean any drain or sewer, either natural or artificial, which is expressly intended for the conveyance of stormwater and uncontaminated water. 
Stormwater means all rainfall runoff, all other surface water and all subsurface water, seeping, percolating or flowing through the soil. 
Total phosphorous means any phosphorous that is bound up in any organic or inorganic compound. 
Total suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, wastewater or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering and are referred to as nonfilterable residue in the laboratory test prescribed in the Standard Methods. 
Township means the Saginaw Charter Township. 
Toxic substance means any pollutant defined by the EPA and any material or substance which alone or with other materials or substances can cause sickness or illness in animal or fish life, cause operational upset and shall include petroleum products. 
Treatment plant means the Saginaw Charter Township Southwest Wastewater Treatment Plant and all other structures or devices under the control and/or ownership of the township and used for controlling and/or treating sewage. 
Uncontaminated water means any water that has been taken in and used by a person and discharged without chemical change and meets the same physical requirements as exhibited before use. 
Upset means an exceptional incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the user. An upset does not include noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation. 
User means any person that discharges sewage, wastewater, wastes or uncontaminated water into the sewerage system. 
Wastes means substances in liquid, solid or gaseous form that is added to discharge water, or otherwise placed, dumped or allowed into the sewerage system by any person. 
Wastewater means combined sewage, together with any water that has been used and degraded or altered physically and/or chemically by any commercial, industrial or private use and discharged as an unwanted substance. 
Wastewater treatment plant means a publicly owned treatment works. 
Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 631, § 2.02, 6-10-2002) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.
