Sec. 78-207. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Applicability of charge. The sewage disposal charge established in this section shall apply to each lot or parcel of land, building or premises (referred to in this section as "premises") from which sewage is discharged into any public combined sewer or public sanitary sewer, and to each premises for which a connection to any sewer is ordered to be installed, and such charges are to take effect upon the expiration of the time limit for the installation of the sewer connection or upon use of such connection for the disposal of sewage, whichever occurs first. 
(b)  Definitions. Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this section and related regulations shall be as follows: 
Debt service charges means the costs of retiring sewage disposal bond issues, including reserve fund requirements, which are assessed to users in accordance with the adopted rates. 
Industrial cost recovery and ICR mean the recovery, by the township from the industrial users of the sewer system, the federal grant amount allocable to the treatment of wastes for such users. 
Industrial user class means the users discharging industrial wastes into the sewerage system. 
Operation and maintenance costs means the costs to operate and maintain the sewerage system, excluding capital costs for new construction. 
Replacement costs means the expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the sewerage system to maintain the capacity and performances for which the system is designed and constructed. 
Residential and commercial user class means the users discharging domestic wastes into the sewerage system. 
User charges means the costs of operation, maintenance and replacement of the sewerage system which are assessed to users in accordance with the adopted rates. 
(c)  Basis of charge. 
(1)  The rates established in this section shall be based upon the amount of water used upon the customer's premises, including water from public and private supplies, or at the election of the customer as provided in this section, upon the amount of sewage discharged to the public sewers. All private water supplies, any portion of which reaches the sewer, shall be metered at the customer's expense and the consumption thereof shall be added to the consumption from the public water supply and the resultant total shall be used to establish the sewage disposal charge. Failure to meter any water supply shall not release the customer from paying the sewage disposal charge thereon. In such case, the meter size required and the total water consumption shall be estimated by the director of general services and shall be conclusive. 
(2)  The rates established in this section shall consist of both a user charge and a debt service charge for all users of the sewerage system. Such charges shall be reviewed annually to ensure they properly reflect the cost of service between user classes and the location of service. 
(d)  Optional arrangement. 
(1)  Any customer may elect to establish metering facilities registering the discharge from his premises to the public sewers. All such arrangements shall be subject to the prior approval of the director; and the expense thereof, including installation, maintenance and operation, shall be borne by the customer. 
(2)  When metering facilities registering the discharge from the premises to the public sewers have been installed as permitted by this section, the readiness-to-serve charge provided for in subsection (e)(1)a. or (f)(1)a. of this section shall be based upon the water meter size, as determined by the director, which would be required if all liquids reaching the sewage metering facilities were delivered through the public water supply. The disposal rate charge provided for in subsections (e)(1)b. and (f)(1)b. of this section shall be applied to the flow of sewage. If the metering facilities shall fail to operate or register the flow correctly, the charge shall be based upon the estimate of the director of general services of the flow of sewage for the billing period. 
(e)  Sewage disposal charges for premises within the township. 
(1)  The net rate charged for sewage disposal for premises classified as residential-commercial users within the limits of the township shall be the sum of the following user charges and the debt service charge: 
a.  User charge based on water consumption, or on the discharge into a public sewer, whichever is applicable, at the rate of $0.50 per 1,000 gallons. An additional charge, in cents per 1,000 gallons, shall be added to such user charge, based upon the township's cost for the purchase of electrical power for municipal pumping purposes during the month immediately preceding the period covered by the customer's bill. Such charge shall be computed by multiplying the township's cost for electrical power, in cents per kilowatt-hour, times 1.550. 
b.  Debt service charge based on the size of each water meter measuring water, any part of which is discharged into a public sewer: 
Meter Size 
(in inches) 	Amount

(2)  The net rate charged for sewage disposal for premises classified as industrial users within the limits of the township shall be the sum of the following user charges and the debt service charge: 
a.  User charge based on water consumption or the discharge into a public sewer, whichever is applicable, at the rate of $0.50 per 1,000 gallons. An additional charge shall be added to such user charge, in cents per 1,000 gallons, based upon the township's cost for the purchase of electrical power municipal pumping purposes during the month immediately preceding the period covered by the customer's bill. Such charge shall be computed by multiplying the township's cost for electrical power, in cents per kilowatt-hour, times 1.550.

(f)  Sewage disposal charges for premises outside the township. 
(1)  The net rate charged for sewage disposal for premises outside the township, classified as residential-commercial users, but excluding the premises for which a different rate is established pursuant to this section, shall be the sum of the following user charges and the debt service charge:

Such charge shall be computed by multiplying the township's cost for electrical power, in cents per kilowatt-hour, times 1.550.

(2)  The net rate charged for sewage disposal for premises outside the township, classified as industrial users, but excluding the premises for which a different rate is established pursuant to this section, shall be the sum of the user charge and debt service charge.

(g)  Wastes exceeding discharge limitations. When it is determined by the director that a user is discharging water or wastes to the sewer system which exceed the limits specified, the following additional charges shall be made for that portion of waste load exceeding the limits: 
a.  Five-day BOD, $0.04 per pound. 
b.  Suspended solid, $0.035 per pound. 
c.  Phosphorus, $0.27 per pound. 
(h)  Penalty. A penalty of ten percent of the amount of the charges made under subsection (e) or (f) of this section shall be added to each bill not paid on or before the due date thereon. 
(i)  Free sewage disposal service. No free sewage disposal service shall be furnished to any person, firm or corporation, public or private, or to any public agency. 
(j)  Collection. Charges for sewage disposal service shall be billed by the water division and collected at the same time and in the same manner as provided for water bills. The water division is hereby authorized to enforce the payment of such sewer service bills by shutting off the user's water supply or an action of assumpsit may be instituted by the township against such user. The charges for sewage disposal service, which under the provisions of Public Act No. 94 of 1933 (MCL 141.101 et seq.), are made a lien on the premises to which furnished, are hereby recognized to constitute such lien; and the director of finance shall, annually, on or about May 1, certify to the township assessor all sewage disposal charges which shall be delinquent for six months, whereupon such charge shall be entered upon the next tax roll as a charge against such premises and shall be collected and the lien thereof enforced in the same manner as general township taxes against such premises are collected and the lien thereof enforced. A like lien for such charges and service shall, to the extent permitted by law, be imposed against property outside the township and shall be enforced as provided in such act, observing procedures similar to the procedures in this subsection (j) as appropriate for township taxes. 
(k)  Agreements. No provision of this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the township and any person whereby sewage or waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the township for treatment, subject to the payment by such person of such additional charges as may be reasonable. Charges for such service shall be as provided by resolution of the township board or by written agreement approved by the township board. 
(l)  Agreements with public officers and agencies. The charges for sewage disposal services furnished to the drain commissioner or to any municipality or public agency shall be provided for by written agreement approved by the township board, the schedule of charges to be set forth in such agreement or in a resolution adopted by the township board. In no event shall such charges be less than the total cost, including all direct and indirect costs of comparable service to premises within the township. 
(m)  User charges and fees. 
(1)  It is the purpose of this section to provide for the recovery of costs from users of the township's sewerage system and treatment plant for the implementation and operation of the pretreatment program established. The applicable charges or fees shall be set forth in a schedule of charges and fees and shall be sufficient to meet costs of operation of the pretreatment program or as provided by law. 
(2)  The township manager shall adopt charges and fees by rule and regulation, subject to the approval by the township board, and such charges and fees shall include: 
a.  Reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the waste control and pretreatment programs established by this section; 
b.  Costs for monitoring, sampling, analysis, inspections and surveillance procedures; 
c.  Costs for reviewing accidental discharge procedures and construction; 
d.  A fee for filing appeals; 
e.  Costs of consistent removal (by the POTW) of pollutants otherwise subject to federal pretreatment standards; and 
f.  Other fees and charges as the township manager may deem appropriate to carry out the requirements of this section. 
The fees and charges established by the township manager shall be based upon the reasonable cost to the township to regulate or perform the action. 
(Ord. No. 631, app. A, 6-10-2002)  
Secs. 78-20878-230. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - NORTHWEST UTILITY AUTHORITY SEWAGE DISPOSAL REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 78-231. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  Saginaw Charter Township is a member of the Northwest Utility Authority, an authority organized pursuant to Public Act 233 of the Michigan Public Acts of 1955, as amended. 
(b)  The Northwest Utility Authority is authorized to adopt rules and regulations, which are enforceable within the boundaries of each of its member municipalities, pursuant to Michigan Complied Laws Section 124.284d, as amended. 
(c)  This township, as a member municipality of the Northwest Utility Authority, is empowered to enforce the rules and regulations of the Northwest Utility Authority within its jurisdictional boundaries, pursuant to MCLA section 124.284d(3), as amended. 
(d)  This township desires to establish concurrent authority to enforce the rules and regulations as adopted by Northwest Utility and approved by this township. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 9-8-2003)  
Sec. 78-232. - Definitions. 
Authority shall mean the Northwest Utility Authority, an authority created under Public 233 of 1955, Michigan Public Acts, as amended. 
Authorized local official shall mean the township ordinance enforcement officer of Saginaw Charter Township. 
Municipal civil infraction action means a civil action in which the defendant is alleged to be responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
Municipal civil infraction violation notice shall mean a written notice prepared by an authorized township official, directing a person to appear in district court and to pay the fine and costs, if any, prescribed for violation of the authority sewage disposal regulations. 
Sewage disposal regulations shall mean the Northwest Utility Authority Sewage Disposal Regulations, as approved by the township board on September 8, 2003 and adopted by the authority, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 2, 9-8-2003)  
Sec. 78-233. - Municipal civil infraction action; commencement. 
A municipal civil infraction may be commenced for violation of the sewage disposal regulations upon the issuance by an authorized official of the township, of a municipal civil infraction citation directing the alleged violator to appear in district court. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 3, 9-8-2003)  
Sec. 78-234. - Municipal civil infraction citations; issuance and service. 
Municipal civil infraction citations shall be issued and served by authorized township officials as follows: 
(1)  The time for appearance specified in a citation shall be within a reasonable time after the citation is issued. 
(2)  The place for appearance specified in a citation shall be the district court of the County of Saginaw, Michigan. 
(3)  An authorized township official may issue a citation to a person if: 
a.  Based upon investigation, the official has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction; or 
b.  Based upon the investigation of a complaint by someone who allegedly witnessed the person commit a municipal civil infraction, the official has reasonable cause to believe that the person is responsible for an infraction. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 4, 9-8-2003)  
Sec. 78-235. - Penalities and sanctions; injunctive relief. 
(a)  Violations and penalties. A person who violates any provision of the sewage disposal regulations, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued there under, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement of the sewage disposal regulations is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of $1,000.00 per day, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. In the case of monthly or other long-term average discharge limits, fines shall be assessed for each day during the period of violation. 
(b)  Fines/schedule of fines. Increased fines may be imposed for repeat offenses. As used in this section, "repeat offense," means a second or any subsequent municipal civil infraction violation of the same requirement or provision of these regulations (i) committed by a person to be responsible. The increased fined for repeat offenses under these regulations shall be in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  For a first repeat offense, the fine shall be $2,500.00, plus costs; and 
(2)  For a second or subsequent repeat offense, the fine shall be $5,000.00, plus costs. 
(c)  Authorized official. The township ordinance enforcement officer and the director of environmental protection and water system management, as provided in the authority's disposal sewage regulations, are hereby designated as the authorized officials, to issue municipal civil infraction citations or municipal civil infraction violation notices as provided in this division and the sewage disposal regulations. 
(d)  Other enforcement action. Issuance of a civil infraction and imposition of a civil fine shall not be a bar against, or a pre-requisite for, taking any other action against the user, as authorized under the sewage disposal regulations. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 5, 9-8-2003) 
 
Chapter 82 - VEGETATION[1]
